Pour acquérir ces équipements Monsieur Koné décida de rechercher des ressources financières additionnelles auprès de l’Institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Avec ce pret de 200.000 FCFA, Il compte achéter un appareil photo professionnel et un Téléviseur pour les Jeux play station payant.

Sa clientèle est constituée de citadains et de ruraux pour la photographie. Pour les jeux play station la clientèle est constituée de jeunes scolaires.

Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA avec lequel il payera les intérêts du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses dela famille.

loans.use:
Purchase of a professional camera and a television

Achat d’un Appareil Photo et un Téléviseur.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama started her local restaurant twenty years ago at Obuasi, where she lives. Since then, she has become one of the popular food vendors in her neighborhood. Ama is 50 years old and married with three children currently in school.

She serves many kinds of local dishes: fufu, rice balls, banku, and ampesi, among others. Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain, and taken with soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. Ampesi is a boiled plantain or yam and it is taken with stew.

Ama wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. Ama hopes to use part of her proceeds to finance her children’s education.

Ama is a member of the community group called "Blessing Trust Group." In this group, members assist one another to provide support in handling loan repayments.

This photograph of Ama was taken during a group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials: bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 44 years old. She is married with three children aged seventeen, fifteen, and twelve years respectively. They are all currently in school.

Mary is a petty trader who trades in maize and ginger. She has been a retailer of ginger and maize for the past twelve years and provides for her family.

Mary wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of maize and ginger to serve her customers throughout the season. She faces increasing food prices due to the current food crisis in the country. The loan will help her with increasing costs and enable her to raise her income to support her children at school.

She belongs to a community group called "Blessing Trust Group" where group members assist one another to provide support in handling loan repayments.

This photo of Mary was taken during a group meeting.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of maize and ginger.

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr:
Mr. Ousmane Koné, 23, is married with no children. Together with his wife, he lives with his father in an extended family in the Torakabougou neighborhood of Bougouni (Bougoni Prefecture, Sikasso Region, Republic of Mali).

He learned this business from his father who was a well-known local carpenter. With 8 years' experience, he enjoys an excellent reputation with the citizens of Bougouni. For this reason he receives a lot of orders for furniture and various repairs.

To satisfy the ever-growing demands of his clientele, he decided to become a member of the Loan Program of Soro Yiriwaso so as to have additional financial resources. This is his first loan with Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan, he intends to purchase 10 sheets of plywood, a table saw, 8 wooden planks, and four bags of nails. He buys his supplies in Bougouni and displays what he makes in a shed in front of his workshop. His customers are inhabitants of Bougouni and those who pass through buying goods for resale.

He expects to make a profit of about US$ 100 per month and with this profit, he will pay the interest on the loan and help his father with family living expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Koné Monsieur Ousmane Koné a 23 ans, marié et sans enfant il vit avec sa femme chez son père dans une famille élargie au quartier Torakabougou de Bougouni (Prefecture de Bougouni Régoin de Sikasso République du Mali ).

Il a appris cette activité auprès de son père qui fut un grand menuisier de la place. Avec une expérience de 8 ans, il jouit d’une notoriété et une grande réputation au niveau des habitants de la ville de Bougouni. Par conséquent il recoit beaucoup de commande de meubles et diverses réparations.

Pour satisfaire les demandes de plus en plus grandissantes de sa clientèle, il décida d’intégrer le Programme de Crédit de Soro Yiriwaso pour obtenir des ressources financières additionnelles. Il est à son premier prêt avec Soro Yiriwaso. Avec ce prêt il compte achéter 10 feuilles de Contre - plaquets, une Scie en tournée, 8 Planches de bois et 4 Sachets de pointes. .Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et expose sa production sous un hangar devant son atelier. Ses clients sont les habitants de Bougouni et les forrains.

Il compte réaliser un bénéfice de 40 000FCFA par mois et avec ce bénéfice, il paiera les intérêts du prêt et aidera son père à assurer les dépenses de la famille.

loans.use:
Purchase of plywood, a saw, planks, and nails

Achat de Contre plaquets, de Scie de Planches et de Pointes.

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Debora is 25 years old and single, and has been selling cakes and meat pies for five years. She prepares and sells these pastries in the afternoon to the working community and bus stops at Obuasi, a busy mining town in Ghana.

Pastries, taken with soft drinks at lunch time are very popular among the Ghanaian working community. This business is source of livelihood for many women.

Debora wants to use the loan to buy more flour, margarine, vegetable oil, etc, to increase stock and avoid price hikes. She believes the loan will help her costs and enable her to raise more income to support her children at school.

She belongs to a community group called "Blessing Trust Group" where group members assist one another to provide support in handling loan repayments.

This photo of Debora was taken during a group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more flour, margarine, vegetable oil, etc.

loans.name: Comité Yboty Group

texts.es:
The committee is comprised of 16 working women from the Yboty of Cabañas company in the city of Caacupé. All of them are informal micro-entrepreneurs and are currently in the 7th cycle of the program for Enterprising Woman. The committee's name, "Yboty", means flower in Guarani, the native language of Paraguay. The women are currently benefiting from a loan of around 718,000 guaranis each (roughly $200 USD).

The group began with its first meetings in the home of Mrs. Marta M. who is currently the group's secretary. One of the characteristics of this group is that they are interested in constantly learning and always ask their assessor Freddy Bordon to school them in specific areas such as marketing, public relations, finances, break even points amongst other topics.

The committee has embarked on a project for the month of June 2008 to host a celebration for Saint John in the neighborhood square. The proceeds will go to helping their neighbor who is currently ill but was once a member of the committee.

Laura, the group leader, expresses the thanks of all the members of the "Yboty" committee to the Paraguayan Foundation for being the only institution that has given them the chance to receive a formal loan to use as working capital and for enabling them to manage their own business.

Today they are requesting a new loan to invest in their mirco-enterprises by purchasing products to be sold in their kiosks such as sugar, meats, rice, vegetables, fruit, candy, soda and others. Those who prepare and sell food, especially "chipa" (a traditional Paraguayan bread with cheese) need to purchase ingredients. The traveling saleswomen in the group will purchase various products including undergarments, clothes and kitchen utensils etc.

Translated from Spanish by Inês Teles, Kiva volunteer.

El comité está compuesto por 16 señoras trabajadoras de la compañía Yboty de Cabañas de la ciudad de Caacupé, todas son pequeñas microempresarias informales y actualmente están en 7to. Ciclo del programa de comité de Mujeres Emprendoras. El comité lleva por nombre “Yboty” que significa flor en el idioma guaraní, idioma nativo de nuestro país. Las señoras actualmente están siendo beneficiadas con un crédito promedio de 718.000 mil guaraníes a cada integrantes.

El comité se inició con las primeras reuniones en la casa de la señora Marta M., quien actualmente cumple la función de secretaria, una de las características de este grupo es que están interesada constantemente en capacitarse, por lo siempre piden a su asesor Freddy Bordón que les hable de algún tema en especial, como ser Marketing, Relaciones Públicas, Finanzas, Punto de equilibrio, entre otros temas.

El comité actualmente se aboca a un proyecto para este mes de Junio, que es la de realizar una fiesta de San Juan en la plaza del barrio, lo recaudado será para ayudar a una vecina quien se encuentra enferma y en alguna oportunidad fue integrante del comité.

La señora Laura, manifiesta y trasmite el agradecimiento de todas las que componen el comité “Yboty” a la Fundación Paraguaya, por ser la única institución que les dio la posibilidad de obtener un préstamo formal para capital de trabajo y a parte el de capacitacitarles para manejar su negocio.

Ellas hoy día solicitan un nuevo crédito para invertirlo en sus micro comercios comprando mercaderías para despensa y kioscos como azúcar, carnes, arroz, vegetales, frutas, golosinas, gaseosas, entre otros. Para las que se dedican a la elaboración y venta de comidas, especialmente “chipa” que es una comida típica parecida al pan con queso, se necesita comprar ingredientes y para las vendedoras ambulantes mercaderías varias como lencerías, ropas, utensilios de cocina, etc.

loans.use: To purchase clothes, sugar, meat, herbs, flour, milk, coal, drins, seeds and garden plants as well as raw materials to prepare 'chipas' such as starch cheese and vegetable oil.

loans.name: Maritza Carolina

texts.es:
Mrs. Maritza Carlona lives in Ciudad Arce located in La Libertad District. Over the past 20 years she has dedicated herself to selling panes con gallina india (a hen sandwhich with tomato sauce typical in El Salvador). Thanks to this business she has raised her two children who are now studying in primary school.

She has been a client of Apoyo Integral for several years and during this time she has managed to keep improving her business. Her profits have been put to good use to meet the demands of her growing clientele.

Another project she is working on with her profits is the construction of a home for her family. She is just starting and needs to build a retaining wall to protect her home from the landslides which often occur in the winter. Her plot of land is 4 meters above the street level and this creates an insecure situation for the inhabitants of the building. Due to all this, Mrs.Maritza is requesting a microloan to continue building her home which in turn will help her provide safety and protection for her two children.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.

loans.use: Construction of a reinforced concrete retaining wall

location.town: Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Mujeres De Fe Group

texts.es: hola mi nombre es Ana L. me dedico a la venta de ropa nueva para dama y caballero, carteras y bolsos para damas, actividad que realizo hace 4 años, tengo 2 hijas que estan pequeños, soy madre soltera,  mi negocio me genera ingresos para aliementar mi familia, en estos momentos necesito inyectarle capital a mi negocio ya que las demandas de los clientes son buenas y necesito mas producto para tener mayores ventas, mi producto lo vendo al credito. necesito la ayuda monetaria para poder hacer crecer mi pequeño negocio.

loans.use: compra de camisas blusas, jeans, pantalones para dama y caballeros, carteras

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en:
Augustine is forty three years old. He is married, but does not have children yet.

He is a retailer of spare car parts and scraps. He buys supplies from spare parts dealers and retails to his customers.

Augustine enjoys his trade very much. However, he is handicapped by low working capital since prices have gone up. He needs this loan to remain in business. He wants to use the loan to buy new stock of spare car parts and scraps to serve his customers. He believes this will enable him to make a good income and expand his business.

He belongs to a community group called "Blessing Trust Group" where group members assist one another to provide support in handling loan repayments.

This photo of Augustine was taken during a group meeting.

loans.use: To buy new stock of spare car parts and scraps.

loans.name: Falilatu

texts.en:
Falilatu is a forty-six year old business woman. She is married with six children. Falilatu is a very hard working and resourceful wife and mother.

Falilatu supplies firewood to food vendors and canteen operators in Obuasi. Firewood is very cost effective to food vendors compared to other energy sources.

Falilatu always seizes good business opportunities. She obtains a supply of firewood from the surrounding villages of Obuasi to serve her customers.

Falilatu wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of firewood to meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to use part of the profit to pay her children’s educational fees.

She belongs to the community group called ‘Ntoboase’ (meaning slow pace) Trust Group. In this group, group members assist one another to provide support in handling loan repayments.

The photograph of Falilatu was taken during a group meeting.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of firewood.

loans.name: María Nohemi

texts.es:
Nohemi lives in the communal settlement of San Andrés in the city of Ciudad Arce, El Salvador. She is a single mother of two children, both of whom help her operate a store in which they sell products for daily consumption. At the same time, Nohemi goes out to sell clothes and sandals in Ciudad Arce in order to generate enough income to improve their living conditions and her family’s life.

Two years ago the organization Apoyo Integral lent Nohemi money in order to strengthen her business. Currently she would like to build a bathroom and put a roof over the corridor, since she will need the roof for protection from the rains and the addition of a bathroom will also make the home a healthier place to live. She is seeking a loan in order to make the aforementioned improvements.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Nohemi vive en el Asentamiento Comunal San Andrés, jurisdicción de Ciudad Arce, es madre soltera de 2 hijos los cuales le ayudan a atender la tienda en la que venden productos de consumo diario, a la vez doña Nohemi sale a vender ropa y sandalias a Ciudad Arce, para lograr generar más ingresos que le permitan mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia. Desde hace 2 años Apoyo Integral le ha brindado créditos para fortalecer el negocio. Hoy quiere construir un baño y techar el corredor, ya que lo necesita para protegerse de las lluvias y tener a la vez más salubridad en la vivienda con la edificación del baño. Por lo anterior expuesto ella esta solicitando un préstamo.

loans.use: To build a bathroom and a roof over the corridor

location.town: Asentamniento Comunal San Andrés, Ciudad Arce

loans.name: Mujeres De Fe Group

texts.es: hola mi nombre es Karla L. me dedico a la produccion y venta de pastelitos de carne, pastelitos dulces y pan de levadura, tengo mi negocio hace unos 5 años, mi producto lo reparto en diferentes pulperias de colonias y a mis vecinos tambien reparto mi producto en la Universidad Nacional Pedagogica de Honduras Francisco Morazan, por lo que estoy solicitando la ayuda para poder incrementar mi produccion ya que la demanda es bastante grande, mi producto se vende porque es bien higienico y barato.

loans.use: compra de manteca, sal, aceite, harina de trigo, coco, minimos, leña, azucar, levadura, condimentos, carne de res y cerdo

loans.name: Villa Dolores Group

texts.es:
The association Villa Dolores is at the center of Villa Tejada. With the help of their loan assistant they work very responsibly in all their group activities.

Almost all of the women are married, with numerous families and they tell us that their daily household expenses surpass the income they receive from their businesses, especially since their children's needs are growing as they get older.

Most of the group sells various goods, primarily as traveling salespeople. They sell, for example, a variety of cosmetics, condiments and sweets amongst other products. They say that in traveling sales, the products are often damaged and have to be cast away. This means they need a reinforcement of capital to enable them to secure a fixed location in markets or on main streets where they will have guaranteed sales and can maintain their products in good condition.
This will lead to improved revenue and a more stable quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Inês Teles, Kiva volunteer

La asociación Villa Dolores pertenece al centro focal de Villa Tejada, con la ayuda de su asistente de créditos trabajan muy responsables en todas sus actividades de grupo.

Casi todas casadas, con familias numerosas nos cuentan que los gastos diarios que tienen en sus hogares sobrepasan al ingreso que obtienen en sus negocios ya que sus hijos van creciendo y necesitan mayores necesidades.

La mayor parte del grupo se dedica a comercio, de distintos productos, venta que la realizan de forma ambulante, por ejemplo, venden variedad de cosméticos, venta de condimentos, venta de dulces y otros. Afirman que este tipo de venta, por el movimiento, maltratan los productos y en ocasiones deben desecharlos por lo que ellas necesitan un refuerzo en su capital para poder obtener puestos fijos en mercados o en principales calles donde obtengan ventas seguras y mantengan sus productos en optimas condiciones. Luego mejorarían sus ingresos y su estabilidad de vida.

loans.use: Capital in order to obtain fixed locations from which to sell their products

loans.name: Mujeres De Potrero Group

texts.es:
The committee consists of 18 working women from the Potrero neighborhood in the city of Caacupé. The group is currently in the 5th cycle of the Mujeres Emprededoras (Enterprising Women) Program and the great majority of the women sell goods from their own homes, using them as stockrooms and stalls. They sell cold drinks and both new and second hand clothes.

The group currently has a loan of around 555.000 Paraguayan guaranis (PYG) per member through La Fundación Paraguaya's Committee of Enterprising Women Program.

The committee was formed thanks for Mrs. María C., the current secretary of the group, who found out through a client of La Fundación that there was a local committees program and that a committee of women had already been formed in her neighborhood. Once she had all the information, she began her campaign, inviting her neighbours to join and that's how the group was formed.

María G., the committee's president has said she is very happy with the Fundación Paraguaya's program because it gives them access to a formal loans, and it is well known that people of scarce means such as those who are part of the committee do not usually have access to formal loans.

Today they are looking for a new loan which they will use to purchase products such as sugar, grass, milk, biscuits, starch, beef, sodas, beer and drinks of all kinds as well as clothes for men, women and children.

Translated by Inês Teles, Kiva volunteer

El comité está integrado por 18 señoras trabajadoras del barrio Potrero de la ciudad de Caacupé, el grupo esta actualmente en el 5to. Ciclo del programa Mujeres Emprededoras, la gran mayoría de las señoras se dedican al comercio, que lo explotan en su misma casa familiar, como ser despensa, kiosko, venta de bebidas heladas, venta de ropas nuevas y usadas.

Las integrantes de comité están manejando una línea de crédito promedio de gs. 555.000 por cada integrante a través del programa de comités de mujeres emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya.

Los inicios y la formación del comité fue gracias a que la señora María C., actual secretaria del grupo, se entero a través de un cliente de La Fundación de que había un programa denominado comités vecinales y que en su barrio ya se había formado un comités de mujeres, una vez que tuvo toda la información se puso en campaña y empezó a invitarle a vecinas y así llegaron a así se conformo el grupo.

María G., la presidenta del comités manifestó estar muy contenta con este programa que emprende la Fundación Paraguaya porque les permite acceder a un crédito formal, ya que es sabido que gente de escasos recursos como las que integramos el comités no tienen acceso a un crédito formal.

Hoy están en busca de un nuevo crédito que desean invertirlo en la compra de productos tales como, azúcar, yerba, leche, galletas, almidón, carne vacuna, gaseosa, cerveza, bebidas de todo tipo, como así también la compra de ropas para damas, caballeros, y niños.

loans.use: To purchase products such as sugar, grass, milk, biscuits, starch, beef, sodas, beer and drinks of all kinds as well as clothes for men, women and children

loans.name: Mujeres De Fe Group

texts.es: hola mi nombre es Mirna R. me dedico a la venta de carteras, mochilas y sandalias tengo 5 años de realizar esta actividad, mis clientes son muy buenos ya que les gusta mi producto y lo que mas les gusta son los precios de mis productos, mi negocio me genera ingresos para el sustento de mi familia, tengo 2 hijos y 1 hija todos estan estudiando para poder ser buenos profesionales, en estos momentos necesito comprar mas producto por tal razon estoy solicitando un credito para poder surtir mi pequeño negocio ya que necesito vender mas para tener mayores ganancias, ya que la situacion economica de nuestro pais esta bien dificil.

loans.use: compra de carteras, mochilas, y sandalias

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Mrs. Fatoumata Konaté, 41, lives with her husband and her 7 children in a traditional African family, together with her husband’s brothers, in the first neighborhood of Koutiala Prefecture, Sikasso Region.

For societal reasons, she was obliged to abandon her studies in favor of taking up a money-earning activity. She makes local soap (Gabacourini) based on residue from cotton processing. She learned this business from a women’s group in the town of Koutiala. She does her work at home.

As she has 8 years’ experience in the manufacture of local soap, her products are very much appreciated by consumers. She sells what she makes in the Koutiala market and at weekly fairs in nearby villages. With the present loan (her 5th loan through Soro Yiriwaso) she plans on buying 6 barrels of cotton residue, 1 barrel of potash, and firewood. She expects to earn an average profit of US$ 120 a month, which she hopes to use to make payments on the loan and help her husband to cover family expenses.

In future, she hopes to be an industrialist (open a soap-making factory).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame Fatoumata Konaté a 41 ans et vit avec son mari et ses 7 enfants dans une famille traditionnelle africaine en compagnie des frères de son mari dans le premier quartier de la préfecture de Koutiala région de sikasso.

Pour des raisons sociales, elle était dans l’obligation d’abandonner les études pour se consacrer aux activités génératrices de revenus. Elle exerce l’activité de fabrication de savon locale (Gabacourini) sur base de résidus des unités de transformation de coton. Elle a appris cette activité auprès d’une association de femme de la ville de Koutiala. L’activité est exercée à domicile.

Avec 8 ans d’expérience dans la fabrication de savon local, sa production est très appréciée par les consommateurs. Elle vend sa production au marché de Koutiala et dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants. Avec le prêt actuel (5e prêt auprès de Soro Yiriwaso), elle compte acheter six (6) barriques de résidus de coton, une (1) barrique de potasse et du bois de chauffe. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 50 000 FCFA par mois, avec .lequel elle espère payer les intérêts du prêt et aider son époux à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.

Dans l’avenir elle envisage être une industrielle (mettre en place une usine de fabrication de savon.)

loans.use:
Purchase of raw material for making soap

Achat de matière première pour le savon

loans.name: Deme (Appui Mutuel) Group

texts.fr:
The Deme Group is made up of four women from Lafiala neighborhood of the town of Koutiala, who have known each other for years. They are 33 years old, on average, are married, and have at least 3 children.

In the interest of growing their businesses, these women became members of the micro-credit program SORO YIRIWASO two years ago. The amount of their loans has risen from US$ 120 for the first loan to the present sum of $240. They have varied businesses (sales of firewood, local cold drinks, take-out food sales, etc.) This loan will be used to purchase a truckload of firewood, sacks of sugar, 2 sacks of “fonio” (a West-African grain), and a considerable amount of ingredients for take-out food.

As they are very experienced in their fields, the products created by the women from the Deme Group are esteemed in the town of Kotiala. With the present loan, they expect to be able to generate a profit of US$ 180 on average. This profit will be used to make payments on the loan and to cover daily living expenses for their families.

In future, the Deme Group intends to have an individual loan of US$ 600 apiece so as to further expand their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Le Groupe Deme est un regroupement de quatre femmes du quartier Lafiala de la ville de Koutiala qui se sont connues depuis des années. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 3 enfants.

Dans leur souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 100.000 FCFA pour le prêt actuel. Elles mènent differentes activités (la vente de bois de chauffe, les boissons locales et glaces, la restauration etc..). Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter la contenance d‘un camion de bois de chauffe, des sacs de sucre, 2 sacs de fonio et une quantité importante d’ingrédients pour la restauration.

Très expérimentées dans leur domaine respectif, les produits des femmes du groupe Deme sont très prisés dans la ville de Koutiala. Ainsi avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 80 000 FCFA. de bénéfice. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérets du prêt et faire face aux charges courantes de la famille.

Dans l’avenir, le Groupe Deme compte obtenir chacun un prêt de 250 000 FCFA pour élargir leur activité.

loans.use:
Purchasing various items for their small businesses

Pour achéter différents articles pour le petit commerce.

loans.name: Kadia

texts.fr:
Mrs. Kadia D., 43, is the mother of 5 children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her 2 co-spouses, and their children in the Sogomougou district of Koutiala, Sikasso Region. Ever since she was little, she has been interested in money-earning ventures, especially the sale of tiéké (a dish made of seasoned manioc sold with fish) which she learned to make working with her sister for 10 years.

After 4 years with SORO YIRIWASO, she has had 5 group loans and is now on her second individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

She does her buying and sells her merchandise in the big open-air market in Koutiala. Her clientele is chiefly composed of merchants, travelers, and people working in and around the market.

This loan will be used to purchase 2 tons of Atiéké which will be warehoused and used bit by bit. She expects to renew this stock every month. Her monthly profit will be about US$ 150.

In future, she wants to become a wholesaler of Atiéké in order to supply retailers in the city of Koutiala and the surrounding villages.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame kadia D. est âgée de 43 ans, mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille polygame avec son mari, ses deux (2) coépouses et leurs enfants au quartier Sogomougou de Koutiala Région de Sikasso. Dès son jeune age elle s’est intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment la vente d’Atièkè (Plat alimentaire fait à base de manioc assaisonné et vendu avec du poisson) qu’elle a appris auprès de sa sœur pendant dix ans.

Après 4 ans de partenariat avec SORO YIRIWASO elle a obtenu 5 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et est à son deuxième prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.

Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Koutiala et effectue ses ventes dans le même marché. Sa clientèle est composée de marchands, de voyageurs et d’ouvriers travaillant dans le marché.

Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter deux (2) tonnes d’Atiéké qui seront stockés et utiliser au fur à mesure. Elle compte renouveler ce stock chaque mois. Son bénéfice mensuel sera de 60000 FCFA.

Dans l’avenir elle veut devenir grossiste d’Atièkè pour ravitailler les commerçants détaillants de la ville de Koutiala et des villages environnants.

loans.use:
purchasing "tiéké" for re-sale

Pour acheter du tiéké

loans.name: Kadiatou

texts.fr:
Mrs. Kadiatou C., 33, is the mother of one child. She is currently getting a divorce so is living with her parents in the Koko district of Koutiala, Sikasso Region, Republic of Mali.

She began to work to earn her living at a very young age since she was not able to continue her studies. Her principal business is selling firewood which she buys from peasants (who supply the city of Koutiala) who have wood-cutting permits. She has a place to store the wood across from her parents' house and she generally retails the wood to a mixed clientele (men and women).

Very experienced in economic matters, she is on her eighth loan with the Microfinance Institution SORO YIRIWASO. All loans were reimbursed appropriately. With this loan, she expects to have a profit of around US$ 280 per month which she will use to make the payments on the loan, support herself and her son, and especially bolster her capital.

Mrs. Kadiatou C. intends in future to get more value from her lot that is designated for housing by putting up a building on it.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame Kadiatou C. a 33 ans, mère d’un enfant (en instance de divorce) ; vit actuellement chez ses parents au quartier koko de Koutiala Région de Sikasso République du Mali.

Elle a commencé les activités génératrices de revenus dès le bas âge parce qu’elle n’a pas pu continuer les études. Son activité principale est la vente du bois de chauffe, qu’elle achète avec les paysans (ravitaillant la ville de Koutiala) et qui détiennent des permis de coupe de bois. Elle dispose d’un lieu de stockage en face de la maison paternelle et vend généralement le bois en détail à une clientèle variée (Femmes et hommes).

Très expérimentée dans les activités économiques, elle est à huitième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance SORO YIRIWASO avec un remboursement correct. Elle envisage de réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 120.000FCFA. qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir à ses propres besoins (ceux de son garçon) et surtout renforcer son capital.

Madame Kadiatou C. compte dans le futur mettre en valeur son lot à usage d’habitation en y construisant un bâtiment. x

loans.use:
Purchase of firewood for re-sale

Achat de bois de chauffe

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Mariam S., 32, lives with her three children and her husband in the Sogomougou district of the prefecture of Koutiala, Sikasso Region. She does livestock fattening (which consists in buying thin animals, caring for them, then reselling them) which she learned from her mother. With 7 years' experience, she is very knowledgeable in each aspect of this undertaking.

Having been with SORO YIRIWASO for four years, she has had a share in 8 group loans which were all appropriately reimbursed. This latest loan will be used to purchase 15 sheep in the villages surrounding Koutiala, 2 sacks of livestock feed, and medicines.The sheep will be fattened over the space of 3 months before being re-sold. Her clientele is essentially composed of buyers coming from Cote d’Ivoire.

She is expecting to make a profit of around US$ 280 every three months which she will use to make the payments on the loan and for daily living expenses.

Mariam finds that this business gives her family a good chance to work together. She hopes to expand her business over the course of time.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Mariam S. a 32 ans, vit avec ses 3 enfants et son mari au quartier sogomougou de la préfecture de koutiala Region de Sikasso. Elle mène l’activité d’embouche ovine (qui consiste à acheter des animaux maigres les entretenir puis les revendre) qu’elle a appris avec sa maman. Avec une expérience de 7 ans, elle maîtrise parfaitement le cycle de cette activité.

En relation avec SORO YIRIWASO depuis 4 ans, elle a eu 8 prêts solidaires qui tous été bien remboursés. Le prêt en cours sera utilisé pour acheter 15 moutons dans les villages environnants de Koutiala, 2 sacs de tourteaux et des médicaments. Les moutons sont engraissés pendant 3 mois avant de les revendre. Sa clientèle est essentiellement composée d’acheteurs venant de la république de Cote d’Ivoire.

Elle compte réaliser un profit moyen de 120 000f CFA par trimestre avec lequel elle payera les intérêts du prêt et assurera ses dépenses quotidiennes.

Mariam trouve que cette activité a crée une bonne cohésion au sein de sa famille. Elle compte élargir son activité au fil du temps.

loans.use:
Purchase of sheep, livestock food, and medicines

Achat de moutons, d’aliment bétail et de medicaments

loans.name: Luz Idalia

texts.es:
Miss Luz A. breeds and sells pigs in her home in the city of Chinandega, located in the county of Somotillo.

She has three school-aged children, and she has to provide for them. She has requested a loan with Ceprodel because she wants to buy the pigs to breed them and then either extract their meat and sell it, or sell the live animals. It is important to note that this is her only source of income, and that is why she makes tremendous effort so that she can continue supporting her children.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio que se dedica la señora Luz A. es a la crianza y venta de cerdos el cual vende en su casa de habitación en la ciudad de Chinandega específicamente en el municipio de Somotillo.

Es una dama con tres hijos en edad escolar los cuales tiene la obligación de mantener y proporcionarles las condiciones necesarias para su desarrollo. Hoy en día ha solicitado un crédito en Ceprodel porque requiere comprar los cerdos para criarlos y luego extraer la carne y comercializarla o si no vender el animal entero a algún cliente. Es necesario destacar que este es su único ingreso que percibe y por esto se esfuerza grandemente para continuar con el mantenimiento de su amados hijos.

loans.use: To buy and breed pigs

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Oumou Koné, 30, is married and has four children between 11 and 3 years old. She lives with her husband and children in Sogomougou district in Koutiala. Like many women in Mali, she did not have the opportunity of going to school and had to find a way to earn income from a young age. After numerous setbacks, she decided to sell local drinks three years ago.

She has received a share of three group loans and one individual loan through SORO YIRIWASO and all have been repaid approporiately. With this latest loan, she is intending to buy 5 sacks of sugar, 10 cases of bags of juice, and 70 plastic bags in Koutiala. The juice powder is mixed with water, flavoring, and sugar to obtain the local drink. Then this drink is put into bags and cooled for several hours. This work occurs daily, and sales are out of the home and at the market. Mrs. Koné's local drinks are very popular and she has a big daily turnover.

In future, she hopes to diversify her business by adding the dyeing of clothing.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Oumou koné à 30 ans, mariée, mère de 4 enfants (qui sont entre 11 et 3 ans). Elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier sogomougou de Koutiala. Comme beaucoup de femmes au Mali, elle n’as pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école et était obligée d’embrancher une activité génératrice de revenus dès son jeune age. Après beaucoup d’échecs, elle décida de vendre des boissons locales depuis trois ans.

Elle a bénéficié de trois prêts solidaires et d’un prêt individuel avec SORO YIRIWASO tous remboursés correctement. Avec le prêt actuel, elle compte acheter cinq (5) sacs de sucres, dix (10) cartons de sachets de jus et 70 sachets plastiques à Koutiala. La poudre de jus est mélangée avec de l’eau, des aromes et du sucre pour obtenir la boisson locale. Ensuite cette boisson est ensachée et mis au frais pendant quelques heures. Cette activité est menée chaque jour et la vente se fait à domicile et au marché. Les boissons locales de Madame Koné sont très appréciées et elle réalise des ventes importantes par jour.

Dans l’avenir elle compte diversifier son activité en y ajoutant de la teinture d’habits.

loans.use:
to stock up on ingredients for juice

Pour acheter des stocks de matière premières pour le jus

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
Ms. Ana A. is arduously dedicated to her fast food business, which she has owned for 30 years. Throughout the years, she has acquired extensive experience in the preparation of delicious meals.

She is from Chinandega, where she runs her business, offering meals and at the same time allowing her patrons to sit and eat on the tables and chairs in her business space.

She now turns to Ceprodel with the aim of obtaining a loan so that she can purchase the ingredients needed to prepare her meals. Both she and her young daughter will greatly benefit from this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Ana A. se dedica muy esforzadamente a su negocio de venta de comida el cual posee desde hace 30 años habiendo adquirido amplia experiencia en la preparación de los deliciosos alimentos.

Es originaria de la ciudad de Chinandega donde posee su negocio en desarrollo donde ofrece los alimentos y a la vez permite que sus clientes se sienten a comer en su local en las sillas y las mesas.

A Ceprodel ha acudido con el objetivo de obtener un crédito para la compra de su materia prima para elaborar los alimentos. Con este crédito se beneficia tanto ella como su familia compuesta por su pequeña hija.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for the preparation of meals

loans.name: Presentacion Del Car

texts.es:
Ms. Presentación del Carmen is a very hardworking person who sells clothing inside the El Bisne market in the city of Chinandega. She is arduously dedicated to her business with the aim of improving its condition and getting ahead so that she can offer her young son better living conditions.

Ever since she started her business, it has steadily been improving and she has been able to acquire greater quantities of merchandise to sell. She currently needs to invest in the purchase of clothing, which is why she is seeking Ceprodel’s backing for a loan that will allow her to purchase merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La dama Presentación del Carmen es una persona muy esforzada que se dedica al negocio de venta de ropa atendida en su propio negocio en el mercado El Bisne de la ciudad de Chinandega. Se dedica muy esforzadamente a su negocio con el propósito de mejorar su condición y salir adelante para brindarle las condiciones de vida necesaria a su pequeño hijo.

Desde que inició su negocio ha ido mejorando hasta adquirir mayores volúmenes de mercadería para sus ventas. La necesidad que hoy en día atraviesa es que necesita invertir en la compra de la ropa y es por esta situación que busca el respaldo en Ceprodel para obtener un crédito necesario para la compra de su mercadería.

loans.use: Purchase clothing

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Mrs. Salimata T., 26, is married and the mother of 4 children (1 son and 3 daughters). She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her co-spouse, and their children in Hamdallaye neighborhood in Koutiala Prefecture.

Salimata is a trained nurse with 4 years of experience. Obliged for societal reasons to abandon this work, she began dyeing and selling damask three years ago. She learned this business from her mother at a young age and presently works out of her own home. Mrs. Salimata T. received a share of 8 group loans through Soro Yiriwaso, all of which were reimbursed correctly. She does her buying in Koutiala and she is intending to buy 1 bale of bazin (damask cloth), 20 kg of dye, and 1 barrel of potash. She sells what she makes in the towns of Koutiala and Niono to a clientele made up of women and men, on credit or on a cash basis. She expects to make a profit of US$ 180 per month which she intends to use to make the payments on the loan and to participate in family living expenses.

Mrs. Salimata T. hopes to open a shop selling hand-dyed basin in Koutiala.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame Salimata T. a 26 ans, est mariée, mère de 4 enfants (1 garçon et 3 filles), vit dans une famille polygame avec son mari sa coepouse et leurs enfants dans le quartier hamdallaye de la prefecture de koutiala.

Salimata est infirmière de profession avec une expérience de 4 ans. Obliger d’abandonner cette activité professionnelle pour des raisons sociales, elle entama l’activité de teintutre et vente de bazin dépuis trois ans. Elle a appris cette activité auprès de sa maman dépuis son jeune age et l’exerce actuellement dans son domicile. Madame Salimata T. a obtenu 8 prêts solidaires (prets de groupe) auprès de Soro Yiriwaso tous remboursés correctement. Elle s’approvisionne à Koutiala et compte acheter 1 balle de bazin, 20 kg de teinture et 1 barrique de potasse. Elle vend sa production dans la ville de koutiala et celle de Niono à une clientèle de femmes et hommes à crédit ou au comptant. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 75.000FCFA par mois qu’elle envisage d’utiliser pour rembourser les intérets du prêt et participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.

Madame Salimata T. compte ouvrir une boutique de vente de bazin teinté à Koutiala

loans.use:
Purchase of bales of damask (very popular cloth in West Africa)

Achat de balles de bazin (Tissus très prisé en afrique de l’ouest).

loans.name: María Azucena

texts.es:
Ms. María Azucena C. sells the finest quality home cooked meals at the El Bisne market in the city of Chinandega.

Her greatest wish is to get ahead with her business and offer her children everything that is necessary for their development. For this reason, she is wisely turning to Ceprodel in order to obtain the loan needed to purchase the ingredients for the preparation of her meals.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

En el mercado El Bisne de la ciudad de Chinandega, la señora María Azucena C. se dedica a su negocio de venta de comida elaborada por sus propias manos habiéndose destacado por preparar excelentes platillos de alta calidad.

Son sus mayores deseos salir adelante en el negocio y brindarles a sus hijos las comodidades necesarias para su desarrollo. Por este motivo es que muy sabiamente acude a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito necesario para la compra de los ingredientes para la preparación de la comida.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients

loans.name: Carmensa Montes

texts.es:
Ms. Carmensa Montes sells fruit on the outskirts of the El Bisne market in Chinandega.

Ever since she started her business, she has reached her goal of improving her humble family’s financial status. With much effort, she leaves for the market early every morning and returns home in the evening to wait for the next day so that she can work. Because of her hard work, Ceprodel has offered her loans. Once again she is requesting a loan in order to purchase fruits and continue with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Carmensa Montes se dedica a su negocio de venta de frutas en las afueras del mercado El Bisne ubicado en la ciudad de Chinandega.

Desde que inició su negocio ha logrado su propósito de mejorar las condiciones económicas de su humilde hogar. Con mucho esfuerzo todas las mañanitas ella sale de su casa hacia el mercado y al atardecer vuelve a su casa para esperar la labor del siguiente día. Por sus grandes esfuerzos es que Ceprodel le ha beneficiado con los créditos. Hoy en día una vez más solicita un crédito para la compra de las frutas y así continuar con su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase fruits

loans.name: Marlene Guadalupe

texts.es:
Lupita (short for Guadalupe), as her customers and friends call her, lives in the city of La Libertad, El Salvador, along with her life partner and their two children.

For the past several years she has dedicated herself to the business of selling bedding (covers and cases for pillows), and her partner has been working as a brick layer.

Through their hard work and the loans they have received from Kiva's field partner Apoyo Integral, both partners have been able to acquire a greater variety of merchandise, meet the demands of their clients, and increase sales. This has helped them generate enough income to maintain their family. Now they would like to begin improving their home through the construction of a perimeter wall that will bring greater security to the whole family. For this reason Lupita is asking for a loan that will help her complete this construction project.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Lupita como le dicen sus clientes y amigos, vive en el Departamento de La Libertad, junto a su compañero de vida y dos hijos que han procreado. Desde hace varios años se ha dedicado al negocio de venta de ropa para camas(Cobertores y forros para almohadas) y el compañero de vida se ha dedicado a realizar labores de albañilería A través del trabajo de ambos y los créditos que durante 3 años le ha brindado Apoyo Integral a podido ir adquiriendo más variedad de mercadería para cumplir con la demanda de sus clientes e incrementar las ventas, que le han generado la manutención de sus hijos. Ahora quiere empezar a mejorar la vivienda, con la construcción de un muro perimetral , que le brinde seguridad a toda su familia. Por ello esta solicitando un préstamo que le permita realizar dicha construcción.

loans.use: Construction of a perimeter wall

loans.name: Argentina

texts.es:
Mrs. Argentina A. is dedicated to selling basic staples and grocery products, as well as meat and all things associated with a general grocery store. She has a great deal of experience since she has been running the business for four years. She has two children and is responsible for maintaining them and providing for all of their needs.

Currently Argentina is asking for a loan through Kiva from the micro-lending group Ceprodel in order to purchase products that she can sell in her grocery store. It is important to emphasize that her dream is to improve her business and thereby distinguish herself as an important businesswoman in the Somotillo sector of Chinandega, Nicaragua, where she is from.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Argentina A. se dedica a la comercialización de productos como son granos básicos abarrotaría , y carnes en general y todo lo concerniente a lo que es una pulpería teniendo gran experiencia ya que tiene 4 años de tener el negocio. Es madre de dos hijos cuyo deber es el de mantener y brindarles todas las condiciones necesarias.

Hoy en día busca el apoyo en Ceprodel para obtener un crédito con el cual adquirir su mercadería para continuar comercializándola en su pulpería. Es necesario destacar que sus sueños son mejorar el negocio y así destacarse como una gran comerciante en el sector de Somotillo de la ciudad de Chinandega de donde es originaria.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for a general store

loans.name: Marta

texts.es:
Marta is married and has two children. She owns a 2 acre plot of land in Caacupé where she grows hens, cows, pigs and other animals.

Marta begins her day at 4h30 AM alongside her husband to begin milking the cows. Most of the milk production is sold from their home since the neighbours visit them to purchase fresh milk.

Twice weekly Marta produces cheese which is often purchased by the chiperos. Chiperos elaborate a typical corn bread which is very popular in Paraguay. Thanks to their hard work they are able to maintain their home and educate their children. Their work is intense and they work every day of the week without a day off. But they know that thanks to their sacrifice they are able to provide for their family so they do all this with lots of love.

Marta is very grateful to the Fundación Paraguya, even if it is true that she must work daily including sundays.

She requests a microcredit to invest in the purchase of corn and feed for her animals.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.

loans.use: Grain and feed purchase (food for cows, pigs and hens).

loans.name: Las Cruces Sololatecas Group

texts.en:
The Las Cruces group resides in Solola, the municipal capital of the Solola state (Lake Atitlan Region), a mountainous perch overlooking Lake Atitlan. The businesswomen expressed contentment with their neighborhoods and town, noting that there were low levels of alcoholism and crime. When asked about the microfinance community Felipa J. said, “we are all like family,” referring to the mutual support in repaying and attending meetings that they give each other.

These entrepreneurs are dedicated to growing vegetables in their family-run fields and selling them in the convenient Solola market. They farm year-round and harvest 3-4 times a year, allowing them to keep consistent sales in the market. Some of the vegetables that they grow include cauliflower, onions, carrots, potatoes, herbs, and cilantro.

Their sales peak on Sundays during market day, and have been consistent enough to maintain entire families at a sustainable earn/spend rate. These loans allow the farmers to think about increasing their output through investment in wholesale seed and fertilizer. Paula C. said that she would buy fertilizer by the pound rather than by the ounce. Some of these women lack tools for the fields where their husbands (and some employees) work. With the increased output, their 3-4 harvests per year would give them a higher yield and consequently more money to invest in their enterprise and in a good quality of life.

The hard work and growth is not solely for having more money. It is, according to Santa Cuj, to be proud about the success of their whole family’s lifelong work, and to be able to send all of their kids to school while having some extra money to live well with. Their dreams include to be happy, to have more clothes, and to build a better house.

Don Jorge was included in the picture because he went to collect his sister´s loan due to her illness.

loans.use: Purchase seeds, fertilizers, insecticides

loans.name: Jardin Atiteca Group

texts.en:
The Jardin Atiteca community from Cerro de Oro is a very small community next to the smallest hump of a volcano in Lake Atitlan. The people enjoy living in such a community where everyone knows everyone. The festive seasons of Christmas and the town fair bring everyone together and give a boost in sales.

Their microenterprise consists of weaving the traditional güipil, the top of the indigenous Mayan outfit, either as a family or with employees (up to 8). To do so, they use the telar de cintura, a weaving method by which one person can weave a güipil in about one day. They then sell this piece for about 150 quetzales (20 USD) to buyers, whether intermediaries, personal contacts or shoppers in the nearby villages of Santiago de Atitlan and San Lucas. Intermediaries take the clothing and sell it to women all around the lake, including women in Panajachel, Solola and Patzun.

There was consensus among the group that their businesses were doing well, since they sell a type of clothing that is not produced very much within Santiago and San Lucas. This low level of competition allows them to sell almost as fast as they produce. So the only thing keeping them from selling more is their limited capital to invest. This is why they are loyal as a group to microlenders and have rarely missed or paid late.

According to the women, the credit has helped their business grow. They can now buy wholesale thread, cloth and dyes. The credit not only helps them buy their materials at a cheaper price, but also helps them be able to produce more items at once. Then, with their savings, they can repay the loans bit by bit.

The clients emphasized that these extra sales allow their business to grow, but most importantly, allow for an increase in income which serves to pay for their children’s educational needs, medicine, and clothing. In addition, this extra money allows them to continue to expand their business, while living a more comfortable life.

loans.use: Purchase thread for weaving güipiles

loans.name: Betty

texts.es:
Betty is a woman of humble origins who together with her husband participates in various jobs depending on the season. She has four children and she is teaching them her business. She is a very hard-working and responsible woman. Betty is requesting a loan to assist her in selling crackers, snacks, canned goods and other items.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

Es una señora D. clase humilD. juntamente con su esposo realizan varias tareas por temporada, mantiene a 4 hijos a los cuales tambien les va enseñando el negocio es una señoara muy trabajadora y responsable. Solicta para mercaderia D. galletas, abarrotes, conservas y otros

loans.use: For the purchase and sale of crackers, snacks, canned goods and other items.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Emprender - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Bugambilia Group

texts.en:
This group of women from Nahuala, Solola is named after a gorgeous flower, Las Buganbilias ( the bougainvilleas), that grows in that region. They expressed contentment with their community, which rarely has conflicts and houses amiable neighbors.

They are dedicated to the creation of home-spun textiles, which they sell as clothing, napkins and blouses mainly to local women in the town market.

Their best day of sales is the Sunday market day. They utilize the loans to buy wholesale cloth and thread in order to labor throughout the week to meet demand. Their loans also allow them money to live well while investing in the more expensive yet ultimately cheaper wholesale elements of their goods. Antonia Coti T. works with her husband in making textiles and now buys much more thread and embroidery supplies. Dominga Tziquin, the group leader, sells stone corn grinders in the Pacific coast towns.

This credit has made things go well for them, according to Manuela C.. The increased flexibility in the balance of funds for living and funds for investment in the business allows their business to grow steadily. Most of their repayments have been so reliable that they have gone from about 100 USD to now almost 800 USD.

The women are unanimously happy to work in the Bugambilias group. “We all know each other and laugh with each other, which makes it easier to repay,” commented Madgaelena T.. She went on to say that they help each other in repayment and remind each other about meeting dates and repayment dates.

These women, although focused on their business dreams such as increasing their amount of credit and the growth of their enterprise, have their true dreams rooted in seeing their children begin life in Guatemala with a head start. They wish to have the money to support a happy family which at the very least has the option financially to send their kids to school and give them a boost. This boost is slowly starting to be seen, as all of the mothers of this group currently send most or all of their children to school, despite the increasing expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of cloth, organic dye and thread

loans.name: Dinh Dung's Group

texts.vi:
• Mr. N. Dinh Dung (ID number: 020027), 50 years old, wants to borrow 150 USD to buy pigs to breed. Besides, he also plants vegetables in the garden and sells them at the supermarket. His average income is 8-9 USD/day. He has repaid his first loan.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Vien (ID number: 020029), needs 125 USD to breed chickens and pigs.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Bang (ID number: 020030), needs 125 USD to breed pigs. .
  • Mrs. N. Thi Hoa (ID number: 020061), needs 125 USD to breed chickens.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Huyen (ID number: 020062), needs 125 USD to breed pigs.
    • (This group has applied, and been posted under ID number 50849 before but with a wrong amount of loan. Now, this group is re-posted with the current ID. The actual amount of loan is 650 USD.)

    Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

    Chú Nguyễn Đình Dũng (MS: 020027), năm nay 50 tuổi. Chú vay 2.478.000 VND về mua lợn chăn nuôi. Ngoài chăn nuôi gia đình chú còn trồng hoa màu, con chú bán hàng ở chợ. Mức thu nhập của gia đình chú là 110.000 VND/ ngày. Chú đã tham gia được 1 chu kỳ vay vốn và đã hoàn trả xong.

  • Chị Nghiêm Thị Viên (MS: 020029), vay 2.006.000 VND về chăn nuôi gà, lợn.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Bang (MS: 020030), vay 2.006.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Hoa (MS: 020061), vay 2.006.000 VND để nuôi gà thịt.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Huyền (MS: 020062), vay 2.006.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn.
  • (Nhóm nay đã được đăng và được cấp ID : 50849 nhưng nhầm số vốn vay. Nay nhóm được đăng lại. Tổng số vốn vay thực tế của nhóm là 10.502.000 VND).

loans.use: Chăn nuôi

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Mrs. Bun S., 45, is married and has five children. She and her husband have owned a plot of farmland growing rice crops and various kinds of vegetables since 1988. 

Besides growing crops, her husband also works climbing palm trees around his house in order to collect palm juice which is refined as palm sugar. With the farming activity, she and her husband makes collectively around $3.50/day. Traditionally, the palm juice refining business is considered  a traditional way of making income for Cambodian countryside people. 

Mrs. Bun S. and her husband are requesting a loan from KIVA to buy more seeds, insecticide and fertilizer to expand their crops in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase insecticide and fertilizer to produce a fertile soil and improved crop production

loans.name: Yan

texts.en:
Mrs. Yan C., 42, is married and resides with her husband and six children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, where she has been working as a farmer since 1980. She works growing rice crops and vegetables on her rice paddy, making only a meager sum of money per day. 

To earn more money to support the family’s expenses, her husband has a business making ice cream which he sells  to a number of people in his town. His profit is around $1.50 per day. The ice-cream business is the main income for the family. In order to expand the ice cream business and make more money, Mrs. Yan C. and her husband have humbly requested a loan to buy more ice cream ingredients ( sugar, salt, peanuts, coconuts and other ingredients). This will allow her husband to produce a larger quantity each day to satisfy their client demand. (Her husband who is working as an ice cream vendor is pictured because his wife was not available.)

loans.use: To purchase more ice cream ingredients to expand the business

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreng S., 51, is a widow and runs her own business at home selling bottles of gasoline to people who use a motor-bike or other type of vehicle in her town. She also has a sewing and clothing design business and makes custom clothing to her client's specifications. Both business activities bring a profit of around six dollars per day of net income.

Two of her children are married and live outside the family’s home. One son who is single lives with her and works as a taxi driver. All income he makes is contributed to his mother.

The taxi business is going well from day-to-day but the taxi is often broken. Mrs. Sreng S. has decided to request a loan from KIVA in the amount of $1000. This money, along with her savings, will allow her son to purchase a new taxi for his business and save them the constant cost of repairs.

loans.use: To purchase a new car for a taxi business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Muhammad Aman

texts.en:
Muhammad Aman, son of J., is one of the residents of the Ningarhar province. He is 55 years old, and there are 6 members in his family. They were living in Peshawar, Pakistan, as refugees since 1985, but recently they have returned to their own country, Afghanistan.

Muhammad Aman is the only financial supporter of his family. He is an old and weak man but he must work and find food for his family, so he is working as a farmer in the agricultural lands near his house. He can't solve his all problems with his small amount of income because his current amount of income is just about $60-70 per month, and it is difficult to solve his all problems. He wants to buy many seeds and increase his products. For this goal, he applied to AFSG for a loan of 30,000 Afghanis, and he hopes that he will improve his business with this money.

loans.use: To buy seeds

loans.name: Barno

texts.en: B. Barno is 45 years old. She is married and the loving mother of one. Having only one son she is doing all she can to make him well-educated and happy. Barno is a market vendor. She sells underwear for women and girls in the local market. She travels to the neighboring city to buy goods, with the help of her son. Generally, the business is stable with a strong possibility to grow. After loans provided by the International Micro-Loan Fund IMON she managed to accelerate the process of development of her business considerably.  With one of the loans, for example, Barno was able to rent one more trading place in the market. Now she plans to increase the working capital to expand her business. She requests $600 US Dollars for the term of 12 months. Barno promises to mange the current loan with accuracy as she did all the previous ones and thanks everyone supporting her.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Samath Ali

texts.en: Samath Ali lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and educated, and he has a grocery store. He loves his business and has good experience in has business. He needs to buy more retail products for his shop, so he wants to take out an individual loan. He wants to succeed in his business and make a good monthly income for his family. He is happy, and he would like to thank both AFSG and Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more retail products

loans.name: Amin Jan

texts.en: This man is Amin J., son of N. J., a resident of the Shewa district of the Ningarhar province. He is 41 years old and marred; there are six members in his family. He has been working as a farmer for the last 12 years, but he faced different financial problems in this business. He didn’t have enough money to buy many seeds and other essential equipment for his land to increase his products and expose them easily to the bazaar. When he heard about the microfinance loans from AFSG, he decided to take a 50,000 Afghanis loan and eradicate the barriers of his business. He wants to improve it as soon as possible, so he applied to AFSG for this goal. He will repay the loan in 24 months.

loans.use: To buy seeds and stocks

loans.name: Mazbut

texts.en: B. Mazbut is 49 years old. He is married and has six children. Her wife is a housekeeper. Mazbut has been providing taxi services for the last 20 years. Each day he transports construction materials of his clients with his lorry. Mazbut dreams that all of his children become well-educated so he works hard to provide them that opportunity. As a result the business generates significant income, allowing him to support his large family. This year is very important for Mazbut as he is going to send one of his sons to the university and arrange the wedding of another son. To provide better service and earn more money, Mazbut needs to purchase spare parts for his lorry. Fixing his lorry will make his business more profitable. With this purpose he requests $600 USD for the term of 12 months. Although this is his first loan, Mazbut is sure that he will repay the loan in time.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for fixing the lorry.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is a 44 year old entrepreneur. She has lived with her family members in Nyamasaria Kisumu for the last twelve years. Her main income-generating activity is charcoal sales, a business she has run for thirteen years. Teresa has also initiated a cereals business, selling beans, green grams, and rice in small scale thus improving her level of income. She requires $400.00 to buy more stock of cereals and charcoal to sell.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To buy stock of charcoal and cereal to sell.

loans.name: Numon

texts.en:
B. Numon is 53 years old. He is married with 5 children.
Numon provides taxi services with his car. He has been in this business for about 20 years and it is the main source of income for his large family. Numon works hard, he gets up early and goes to bed late, trying not to lose any client. The business is successful and generates stable income for Numon's large family and his mother and father. However, the business also needs some funding. Numon plans to fix his car to provide higher quality services to make more profit in order to send his daughter to university. Numon requests 2000 Somoni ($600 USD) for the term of 9 months. He is planning to purchase spare parts for his car. He thanks all for supporting him and promises to manage the loan with accuracy in time.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for the car.

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.en:
B. Gulchehra is 40 years old. She is married and the loving mother of three school agechildren. Her husband is a taxi driver. Despite of her lack of education she has been running her own business for seven years. Gulchehra is a market vendor. She sells kids clothing in the local market. Being hard-working and polite by her nature she has managed to obtain a clientele that is happy with her goods and services. The business is successful and generates stable income for the family. Gulchehra loves her children very much and she wants all of them to be well-educated. With this purpose she wants to send all of her children to university after finishing school.       
Today Gulchehra requests $600 US Dollars for the term of 12 months. She plans to use the loan to purchase new summer clothing. She hopes to raise her income to support her elder son university tuition, as he finished high school this year. Gulchehra expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her and promises to repay the loan in time. Let’s support this brave woman who has a lot of courage and strength to live.

loans.use: To purchase kids clothing to increase inventory

loans.name: Hakimjon

texts.en:
D. Hakimjon is 32 years old. He is married with two children, the elder is 8, and the younger is 6 years old. Hakimjon produces “tandir”- the traditional tajik oven for baking the national bread “lepeshka”. All the national breads are cooked in a “tandir” as it is tastier. He learned this business from his father. He has been in this business for 13 years already. For these years Hakimjon has becmoe the real expert in his business and has a lot of clients. Since Hakimjon has a lot of clients and demand, the business is very successful and brings stable and significant income to Hakimjon, improving the living conditions of his family. Now Hakimjon has a great order for producing tandirs. 
Hakimjon requests $475 US Dollars with the term of 12 months to purchase the input materials for producing tandirs. With your help this will be possible. Hakimjon expresses his gratitude to everyone for supporting him.

loans.use: To purchase the input materials for producing the “tandir” for baking the national bread “lepeshka”

loans.name: Khusrav

texts.en: J. Khusrav is 33 years old. He is married with three children. Her wife is a housekeeper and she takes care of their children. Khusrav has a minivan and provides transport of passengers within the city of Istaravshan. After 10 years he has gained extensive business experience. Initially he rented the car, but with time and savings, he bought his own minivan. The business is stable and generates considerable income for Khusrav’s family, allowing them to improve living conditions. However, the business also needs some funding. Khusrav plans to fix his car to provide higher quality services in future. Khusrav needs to purchase spare parts and to pay for the repair of the minivan. With this purpose he requests $600 US Dollars for the term of 12 months. This is the first loan for Khusrav and he would like to thank all for their trust and promises not to let anyone down with the loan repayment. He is counting on your help. Your support will really help him.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to repair his minivan.

loans.name: Olim

texts.en: Z. Olim is 28 years old. He is married and has two kids. His wife works as a cleaner and guard in the local school. Olim is a market vendor. He has been selling fruit and vegetables since he was a young boy, only 13. For these years Olim has acquired the knowledge and skills required for the business. For instance, he knows how to store fruit to keep their marketable conditions and not to lose their taste and useful properties. He sells fruit and vegetables such as apricot, apple, tomato, and cucumber  in the center local market. Olim begins his workday early morning at 5:00 a.m. Buying vegetables and fruit from the local farmers, he resells them in the market. In the market he is known because of attractive prices and friendly service. All this allows Olim’s business to generate a stable considerable income for his family. Due to the season now Olim’s selling goods are in great demand. For this reason he would like to purchase the new, fresh fruits and vegetables for selling. He requests a loan of $600 US Dollars to expand his business. With your help, this will be possible. He promises to repay the loan within 12 months and thanks everyone for supporting him.

loans.use: To increase of the range of fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Khudoynazar

texts.en: Z. Khudoynazar is 30 years old. He is married with three children. Khudoynazar’s children are young now, but he is already working hard in order to ensure the best future for them. His wife is a housekeeper and she takes care of their kids. Khudoynazar is a farmer. He has worked the land for six years. The business is stable and the main source of income of Khudoynazar’s family. Khudoynazar is growing onion, wheat, cucumber, potato and other vegetables, working the fields from early morning till late night. Five years ago Khudoynazar started from growing onion on a 0.10 Hectare plot. Today he is growing onion and other vegetables on a 1.20 Hectare plot. Khudoynazar requests $1000 US Dollars for the term of 10 months to purchase seeds, mineral fertilizer, and to pay salaries for hired seasonal workers. Khudoynazar thanks everyone for trusting and supporting him today. He promises to pay the loan in a timely manner. Be an important part of the growth of Khudoynazar’s business.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, mineral fertilizer, and the salaries for the hired seasonal workers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of inverter parts and other materials for a small inverters repair shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of clothing in bulk to resell in her community.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in used clothing for a small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of beauty products and clothing to restock a small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of clothing to expand a small business of selling beauty products

loans.name: Shavkat

texts.en: I. Shavkat is 46. He’s married and the father of 6 children. Her wife Gulnora is a housekeeper. Shavkat is working hardto support his large family and to make all of his children well-educated. His business includes growing and selling agricultural such as onion, garlic, potatoes and maize. At the same time he raises cattle. His eldest son helps him with the business. Having been in business for fifteen years, Shavkat has gained rich experience. The business is the main source of income and generates stable income for the family. At the same time it requires considerable capital. The sowing season is beginning soon and he is planning to sow onion, garlic, potatoes and maize, so he wants to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer.  He requests a loan of $875 USD for 12 months. He promises to be accurate with paying the loan.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in a small flour mill machine and other raw materials for a small confectioner's shop.

loans.name: Nigora

texts.ru:
Nigora R. lives in Dushanbe. She works at the “Korvon” market. She has a sales location at the market where she sells women’s clothing. Nigora has been in this business for 5 years. She plans to take out a loan in order to increase her inventory and topurchase products for the school season. Nigora brings her products in from Bishkek.

Nigora has a big family, she is married and has 3 children. They live together happily. Nigora herself is very cheerful and joyful. She will pay back her loan over a 12 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Раджабова Нигора проживает в городе Душанбе. Работает на рынке «Корвон» . Имеет торговую точку , гдек продает женскую одежду. Занимается этим видом бизнеса уже пять лет. Планирует получить кредит для того , чтобы увеличить товарооборот и завести товар к школьному сезону. Товар привозит из города Бишкек. У Нигоры большая семья. Она замужем и у нее трое детей. Живут дружно и весело. Сама Нигора очень жизнерадостная и веселая .Погасить кредит сможет в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Saipocho

texts.ru:
Saipocho M. lives in the Rudaki region. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband does not have a job, but Saipocho has a store next to her home where she sells food products. She has been in this business for 10 years. This business helps her to feed her family. Saipocho would like to take out a loan to update her inventory. She will pay back the loan over a 12 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Махадбекова Сайпочо проживает в районе Рудаки. Замужем и имеет троих детей. Муж нигде не работает , но он имеет магазин рядом со своим домом. Торгует продуктами питания . Занимается этим бизнесом уже 10 лет. Этот бизнес и помогает ей прокормить семью. Хочет обновить ассортимент путем получения кредита. Погасить кредит сможет в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Homid

texts.en: K. Homid is 44 years old. He is married with an amazing daughter. Homid has been running his own café, cooking shish kebab for 14 years. His café is located close to his house. On average he services 20-25 clients a day. His wife and daughter help him with the business. Homid uses only the best inputs in his café. Thus the business is stable and brings considerable income for the family. This year is very important for Homid as he is going to arrange the wedding of his dearest daughter. Homid plans to expand his business to earn more money. With this purpose Homid requests $400 US Dollars for the term of 12 months. He is planning to purchase meat and coal for his café. This amount would help him accomplish his goals in a short time. Homid wants to thank everyone supporting him.

loans.use: To purchase meat and coal for his café

loans.name: Uktam

texts.ru:
Uktam M. lives in the Rudaki region. He is married and has 4 children. Uktam rents a location where he runs a cafeteria and works as the chef. Uktam has been in this business for 5 years. He would like to remodel the premises and needs a 12 month loan to do this. This will allow him to attract new customers and to improve working conditions.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Мирзоев Уктам Житель района Рудаки. Женат и имеет четверых детей. Арендует помещение , которое использует под столовую. Работает поваром . Занимается этим бизнесом уже пять лет. Хочет отремонтировать помещение , для чего и запрашивает кредит сроком на 12 месяцев.Это поможет привлечь новых клиентов улучшить условия работы.

loans.use: Remodel cafeteria

loans.name: Shodigul

texts.ru:
Shodigul H. lives in Vahdat. She is 59 years old, is married and has 6 children. Shodigul has a small plot where she raises livestock. She would like to use a loan to purchase a calf. This will help her to increase the number of animals that she own. She plans to pay back the loan over a 12 month period.

Shodigul’s husband is in Russia to earn extra money and as a result Shodigul bears all the responsibility for providing for her family.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Холова Шодигуль проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 59 лет , замужем и имеет шестерых детей. Имеет небольшое хозяйство , где разводит крупно-рогатый скот. Хочет воспользоваться кредитом для покупки бычка. Это поможет увеличить поголовье скота. Погасить кредит планирует в течении 12 месяцев. Муж уехал в Россию на заработки , поэтому вся ответственность по обеспечению семьи лежит именно на Шодигуль.

loans.use: Purchase a calf

loans.name: Thuo

texts.en: Mrs. Thuo C. R. is 24 years old and married with one little daughter. She has a stand in front of her house selling grocery products, household stuffs, coconut and vegetables to the people in her community. Each day, she typically makes around $5 profit. Her husband works as a motor-taxi driver and makes $6 per day gross, but the cost of gasoline and out-of-control inflation in Cambodia is drastically reducing his profit. To offset this and expand her business, Mrs. Thuo C. R. is requesting a loan to purchase more grocery products to keep pace with her customers' demands.

loans.use: To purchase more wholesale grocery products to satisfy her customers

loans.name: Talbi

texts.ru:
