Córdova, member of the Credit Group known as “Las Golondrinas” who lives in the department of San Martín, Province of San Martín and District of Tarapoto, sells parts for cars, motorcycles, and motokars (a 3-wheeled motorized “rickshaw” vehicle). Her business is located in her own residence. She decided to open this business because her husband is a mechanic, and she saw the need they had to travel downtown into the city in order to buy car parts. With this loan of $350.00, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will purchase many different types of parts, automotive fluids, and oil in order to outfit her business and secure sales of the parts which are the most vital to the business. She is married, 37 years old, and has 2 children in school. Like all mothers she would like to see her children become professionals, and thanks to her business they are achieving this. She is a very optimistic and self-assured person and she wants to run her business in the best way possible.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy, a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Zadith P. Córdova socia del Grupo de Crédito mientras tanto “Las Golondrinas” vive en el departamento de San Martín, Provincia de San Martín y Distrito de Tarapoto, se dedica a la venta de repuestos de motos, motokar y carros, su local se encuentra ubicado en su propia casa en el Jr. Jorge Chávez Nº 1371. Su esposo la motivo aperturar este negocio, por que él es mecánico, viendo la necesidad de que tenían que trasladarse al centro de la ciudad para comprar los repuestos de los vehículos, optaron en poner este negocio. Con el préstamo recibido de S/. 1 000.00 que los pagará en 4 meses, compró diversos modelos de repuestos y accesorios para motos, motokar y carros, como ponchos para palier, terminales, rodajes, resortes, etc. así mismo compró liquido de freno, crucetas y aceite para surtir su negocio y tener asegurado sus ventas, por que son los repuestos que tienen mas salida. Ella es casada, cuenta con 37 años y 2 hijos que están estudiando y como toda madre desea ver a sus hijos profesionales, gracias a su negocio lo esta logrando, ella es una persona muy optimista y segura de si misma, quiere implementa mejor su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of car parts for different models. Purchase accessories and oil wholesale.

loans.name: Liz Vani

texts.es:
Mrs. Liz Vani D. G., who belongs to the group “Las Solidarias” and lives in the region of San Martín, Province of San Martín, District of Tarapoto, sells groceries from a store in her home. Liz is a very young woman who, in her short life, has had to find her own way of supporting herself, and she came up with the idea of locating her business in her own home. With a loan of $250.00, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy the items most needed such as milk, oil, cocoa, different brands and sizes of detergent, flour, soft drinks of different flavors and in addition she will buy carbonated beverages in order to satisfy the needs of her customers. She is 23 years old and has a very young daughter who is her “little lady.” She is a woman who is driven to get ahead in her business, she wants to put her plan into action and supply all of the products that her customers ask for.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy, a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Liz Vani D. G. pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto “Las Solidarias” vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia de San Martín, Distrito de Tarapoto se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, su negocio esta ubicado en su propia casa en el Jr. Huallaga Nº 480. La señora Liz es una mujer muy joven que a su corta edad ha tenido que buscar la manera de obtener sus propios ingresos y no tuvo mejor idea que poner su negocio en su misma casa. Con el préstamo recibido de S/. 700.00 que lo pagará en 4 meses, comprará artículos de primera necesidad como leche, aceite, cocoa, detergentes de diferentes marcas y tamaños, harina preparada, refrescos de distintos sabores, además comprará bebidas gasificadas para satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes. Tiene 23 años y una hija mujercita que todavía es pequeña, ella es una mujer con muchas ganas de salir adelante en su negocio, desea implementarlo y surtirlo con todos los productos que solicitan sus clientes.

loans.use: To purchase various grocery items at wholesale.

loans.name: Martha Luz

texts.es:
Mrs. Martha Luz P. T., who is a member of the Community Bank “Sembrando Futuro”, lives in the Región San Martín and Province of San Martín and district of Tarapoto. She sells all types of refrigerated goods, such as juices, cakes, humitas (tamales), chicken sandwiches, eggs, etc. She started the business very young and has always enjoyed working with people. The economic situation motivated her to begin this business, and she could see that it was a good option in the neighborhood she lives in. The loan will be repaid in 6 months, and will be used to buy the ingredients needed to prepare her refrigerated products such as sugar, algarrobina (a type of syrup), malt, boxed milk, flour, butter, eggs, corn, and local fruits. Additionally, she will purchase a blender, dishware, and glasses appropriate for the sale of juices. She currently is 25 years old, and is the mother of two minor children who are everything to her. With her friendly manner she attends to her customers who come to see her every morning. In the future she hopes to add a dressmaking shop which will bring economic stability.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Martha Luz P. T. es socia del Banco Comunal “Sembrando Futuro”, vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia de San Martín y distrito de Tarapoto, se dedica a la venta de todo tipo de refrigerios, como jugos, kekes, humitas, sanguches de pollo, huevo, etc. Se inició en el negocio desde muy joven, siempre le gustó estar en contacto con la gente, la situación económica que estaba pasando la motivó a iniciarse en este negocio, por que vio que es una buena alternativa en el barrio donde vive. El crédito recibido de S/. 1300.00, que será pagado en 6 meses, compró los ingredientes que necesita para la preparación de sus refrigerios como: azúcar en sacos, algarrobina, malta, leche en cajas, harina preparada, mantequilla en kilos, huevos en casilleros para la preparación de los kekes, maíz para preparar las humitas y frutas de la región. Además comprará una nueva licuadora, vajillas, vasos apropiados para la venta de jugos. Actualmente tiene 25 años, y dos hijos menores por quienes velar y luchar, con su amabilidad que le caracteriza atiende a sus clientes que le visitan todas las mañanas, en el futuro piensa instalar un taller de costura que le permita una estabilidad económica.

loans.use: Purchase of consumables. Purchase of one blender, dishes, and glassware.

loans.name: Josefa

texts.es:
Mrs. Josefa S. F. is a member of the Community Bank “Virgen de la Inmaculada”, and lives in the Región San Martín, Province of San Martín and district of Tarapoto. She sells refrigerated goods such as soft drinks, cakes, humitas (tamales), juanes (similar to a tamal, except made with rice, spices, a stuffing, and wrapped in leaves), and regional sweets. She entered the business world 10 years ago. She is a very dedicated, hardworking woman, with the drive to continue her success in the business world. She tells us that she previously sold eggs at a stand in the market, and that now she owes her success to her ability to treat her customers well and she has earned their loyalty. The loan will be repaid within 6 months and will be used to purchase the ingredients needed to prepare her products, such as rice, sugar, oil, flour, masa flour for the humitas, butter, eggs, and other ingredients with which she will create her delicious dishes. Josefa is 63 years old, is known for her patience and perseverance, and wishes to become economically stable in order to enjoy a life that is tranquil and worry-free as she ages.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy, a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Josefa S. F. es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen de la Inmaculada”, vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia de San Martín y distrito de Tarapoto, se dedica a la venta de refrigerios: como: refrescos, kekes, humitas, juanes y dulces de la región. Se inició en el mundo del negocio hace 10 años, ella es una mujer decidida, muy trabajadora, con muchas ganas de seguir triunfando en el mundo del negocio, nos cuenta que anteriormente vendía huevos en un puesto en el mercado, y que ahora se dedica a la venta de refrigerios gracias a su simpatía que demuestra se ganó el aprecio y la fidelidad de sus clientes. El crédito recibido fue de S/. 2000.00 para ser pagados en de 6 meses con lo que comprará los ingredientes que necesita para la preparación de los refrigerios como: arroz en sacos, azúcar en sacos, aceite en litros, harinas, maíz choclo para la preparación de las humitas, mantequilla en kilos, huevos en casilleros y otros ingredientes que se empleara para que salga agradable sus ricos potajes. La señora Josefa, tiene 63 años, ella se caracteriza por tener mucha paciencia y perseverancia ya que desea estabilizarse en su economía, para tener una vejez tranquila y libre de preocupaciones.

loans.use: Purchase of wholesale consumable ingredients.

loans.name: Rister

texts.es:
Mrs. Rister M. G., member of the Community Bank “Virgen de la Inmaculada”, lives in the Departament of San Martín, province de San Martín, District de Tarapoto. She sells beauty products and other items such as shoes, wallets, etc. She sells primarily by taking orders. She began working in this field three years ago and she sells perfumes and cosmetics of different brands such as ESIKA, AVON, and UNIQUE, which she sells through orders and by catalog and she also maintains a supply in her home. She supplements her income with the preparation and sale of humitas (tamales) and juanes (similar to a tamal, except made with rice, spices, a stuffing, and wrapped in leaves) which she makes to order for special events such as birthdays, weddings, quinceañeros and others. With the the loan of 1,300 Peruvian Soles, which will be returned in six months, she will buy various items such as perfumes, creams, shampoos, soaps, makeup, deodorant, lipstick, and also shoes. In addition she will buy ingredients for the preparation of the refrigerated foods which will allow her to complete orders and satisfy the needs of her customers. She is 60 years old, lives with her husband and daughter, who is studying at the university. It is because of her family that she works day alter day with such perseverance. One of her goals is to have a trimmings (embellishments for clothing and other textiles) shop because there is nothing like that in her neighborhood, and another goal is to see her daughter become a professional.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy, a Kiva volunteer.

Compra de artículos de belleza. Comapra de insumos. Description La señora Rister M. G., es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen de la Inmaculada”, vive en el Departamento de San Martín, provincia de San Martín, Distrito de Tarapoto, se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza, y otros artículos como zapatos, carteras, etc, sobre todo trabaja con pedidos, su negocio esta ubicada en su propia casa en la Av. Lima Nº 830. Se dedica a este tipo de negocio hace 3 años ella vende artículos de perfumería y cosméticos de diferentes marcas como ESIKA, AVON, UNIQUE, que lo vende a través de pedidos y por catalogo y que también tiene un Stock en su casa. Complementa su negocio con la preparación y venta juanes, humitas, que los prepara a pedido eventos especiales como: cumpleaños, matrimonios, quinceañeros y otros Con el crédito recibido de S/. 1,300.00 que será devuelto en 6 meses, comprará diversos artículos como perfumes, cremas, champús, jabones, maquillajes, desodorante, lápiz labial y otros además zapatos, también comprará insumos para la preparación de los refrigerios y así atender sus pedidos y poder satisfacer los gustos de sus clientes. Tiene 60 años, vive con su esposo y su menor hija, que está estudiando en la Universidad, por quienes día a día trabaja con mucha perseverancia. Una de sus metas es tener un negocio de pasamanería porque ve que falta este tipo de negocio por su barrio, otra de sus metas es ver a su hija realizada con una profesión.

loans.use: Purchase of beauty products/cosmetics and consumables.

loans.name: Villa Progresivo Group

texts.en:
Alexandra P. is a young and ambitious female entrepreneur from Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. She first learned the practice of selling clothes at the age of ten in her mother’s small restaurant. When her mother passed away a year later, it became her livelihood and her only means of survival. Now, Alexandra primarily sells men's pants, t-shirts, and shoes in the streets and offices of the nearby community, VilL. Progreso. It is her dream to someday own her own boutique men’s clothing store.

Alexandra is one of the coordinators of the 10-person micro-bank, VilL. Progresivo, which means “Progressive Village”. Each of these unique Dominican entrepreneurs unite in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own. The concept of this group bank paying their loan together is to reduce the risk of one person defaulting, as the others members gladly help cover one another’s payments in order to receive their next loan together. Some of the other women in this particular bank make a living selling clothing, running small salons, and selling sweets on the street. This Kiva loan will go towards the entire group and be divided among the members to pay back.

On behalf of Alexandra, the VilL. Progresivo group, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support and awareness of the global issue of poverty, in which your efforts are helping to make a difference.

loans.use: To purchase men's pants, shirts, and shoes for sale in the streets, as well as hair products and ingredients for cooking deserts.

loans.name: Teresa Del Pilar

texts.es:
Teresa Del Pilar C. M. es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen de la Inmaculada”, lives in the Departament of San Martín, province de San Martín, District de Tarapoto. She sells beauty products (ESIKA, AVON, UNIQUE), and her customers are friends who in turn recommend other customers to her. Her customer base is always growing. Teresa studied to be a secretary, but since she was a child, she has always had a head for business. She started by selling clothing, and two years ago became a beauty consultant. She is enjoying the experience of selling by order and now has a steady customer base. With the loan of 1000.00 Peruvian Soles, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy various items such as perfumes, talc, creams, shampoos, soaps, cosmetics, deodorant, and other products. In addition, she will buy jewelry items such as earrings, chains, bracelets, and rings, in order to keep them in stock, vary her selection, and satisfy the tastes and demands of her customers. Teresa is a 33-year-old woman who lives with her husband and three children. She has the desire to move forward and explore new paths, and would like to have a well-equipped business.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy, a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Teresa Del Pilar C. M. es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen de la Inmaculada”, vive en el Departamento de San Martín, provincia de San Martín, Distrito de Tarapoto, se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza (ESIKA, AVON, UNIQUE), sus clientas son sus amigas quienes le recomiendas a otras personas así va creciendo su numero de clientes. Teresa estudió Secretariado Ejecutivo pero desde pequeña se inclinó mas por el negocio, ella se inicio vendiendo ropas, pero hace 2 años es consultora de Belleza, la experiencia le agrado mucho, y vende a través de pedidos, actualmente ya tiene cliente fijos y conocidos. Con el crédito recibido de S/. 1000.00 que será devuelto en 6 meses, compró diversos artículos como perfumes, talcos, cremas, champús, jabones, maquillajes, desodorante y otros productos más, también comprará artículos de bijouteria como aretes, cadenas, pulseras, anillos de diferentes modelos, para tener en stock y variar sus productos y poder satisfacer los gustos y exigencias de sus clientes. Teresa es una mujer joven de 33 años vive con su esposo y sus 03 menores hijos, con ganas de salir delante y emprender nuevos caminos, anhela tener un negocio de abarrotes bien surtido.

loans.use: Purchase of beauty items and jewelry.

loans.name: Rofelia

texts.es:
Rofelia G. P. is a partner of the LAS MARGARITAS II communal bank. She lives in the department and province of San Martin in the Banda Shilxcayo district.

She is a professor who, upon not being able to find a teaching position, decided to go into business. She chose to invest in CD's and DVD's to sell and rent. District residents, who frequent Rofelia's business to find their favorite films and music videos, are her clients. Rofelia's moderate pricing and amiability have increased her sales.

The loan of S/.1000.00 will be re-paid over the course of 4 months and will be used to buy CD's and DVD's of a variety of music, films and cartoons, so that clients will be able to find everything they want and are looking for.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Rofelia G. P., es socia del banco comunal “LAS MARGARITAS II”, vive en el departamento y provincia de San Martín y distrito de la Banda Shilxcayo, se dedica a la venta y Alquiler de CD Y DVD de distintas variedades como películas y músicas, su negocio se encuentra ubicado en su propia casa en el Jr. José C. Mariátegui Nº 158 del distrito.

Es profesora pero al no encontrar un puesto de trabajo, decidió dedicarse al negocio, optando en invertir en CD y DVD ella los vende y alquila, teniendo como clientes a los pobladores del barrio que recurren buscando sus películas y videos musicales favoritos , el precio cómodo y la amabilidad que tiene hace que se incrementen sus ventas.

El crédito recibido de S/. 1000.00 que será devuelto en el transcurso de 4 meses, comprará CD’s Y DVD’s de distintas músicas, películas y dibujos animados, de manera que los clientes encuentren todo lo que deseen y buscan.

loans.use: Purchase of various CD's and DVD's

loans.name: Comité San Pedro Group

texts.es:
The San Pedro Group was formed on May 21, 2008. Said group was organized thanks to the current president, Ramona O., who works selling fruits and vegetables. She began investigating how the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras program worked, approaching the advisor during a weekly meeting she was having in the neighborhood. Mrs. Ramona O. started telling her neighbors about it and organized a meeting of 16 women who today make up the San Pedro Group.

The members of this group use their loans for different activities including selling fruits and vegetables, clothing, candies, refreshing remedies, food and beverages, linen goods, aluminum items, sheets, handcrafted clothing and needlework.

The also actively participate in weekly meetings and do other activities to make money like food fairs and raffles. The group works together and demonstrates camaraderie and solidarity.

Today the women would like another loan that will allow them to continue to increase their income from sales.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

El Grupo denominado San Pedro, se formó el 21 de mayo del 2008. Dicho grupo fue organizado gracias a que la actual presidenta, Ramona O., quien se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras, comenzó a averiguar acerca de como funciona el programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, acercándose a la Asesora en una reunión semanal que la misma tenía en el barrio. La señora Ramona O. comenzó a comentarles a sus vecinas y logró juntar a 16 mujeres las cuales integran hoy día el Comité San Pedro.

Las integrantes de este grupo destinan su crédito a diferentes actividades tales como: venta de frutas y verduras, venta de ropas, golosinas, remedios refrescantes, venta de comidas y bebidas, venta de lencerías, venta de artículos de aluminio, venta de sábanas y ropas artesanales, trabajos en costura, etc.

Las mismas participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y realizan actividades extras para recaudar fondos como ferias de comidas y rifas. El grupo trabaja en forma conjunta, demuestran compañerismo y solidaridad.

Hoy ellas están deseosas de retirar un nuevo crédito que les permita seguir incrementado sus ingresos de venta.

loans.use: Purchase fruits, vegetables, aluminum items, ingredients to prepare food, pots, charcoal, hosiery, clothing, candies, linen goods, sheets, handcrafted clothing and fabric.

loans.name: Quely

texts.es:
Mrs. Quely G. Ruiz is a member of the “Las Margaritas II” Communal Bank. She lives in the San Martin region of Peru, in the Province of San Martin, District of Banda de Shilcayo. She makes money renting internet stations at an internet café located in her home, which is situated next to a major road.

Quely used to sell sweets but she had to be away from home quite a lot and decided to get another job for the wellbeing of her children, who still needed her care. She chose a business that would allow her to keep an eye on her children and at the same time improve her finances. She took advantage of the lack of an internet café in her neighborhood and was the first to open an internet café and build clientele.

With the loan of 800 soles ($275), which she will repay over four months, she will buy a printer and furniture for the internet stations which are necessary for the implementation of her business.

Mrs. Quely is 40 years old and lives with her husband and her two children who support her in everything she does. She knows that she has to work hard every day to achieve her goals. She is a very hard-working woman and a dreamer.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Quely G. Ruiz es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Margaritas II”, vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia de San Martín y distrito de la Banda de Shilcayo, ella genera sus ingresos dando servicio de alquiler de cabinas de Internet, su negocio se ubica en su propia casa situada en la carretera marginal sur.

Anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de golosinas, pero tenia que salir mucho, por eso decidió cambiar de actividad para buscar el bienestar de sus hijos por que aun necesitan de cuidado, opto por este negocio que le permite estar pendiente de ellos y a la vez mejorar su economía, aprovecho la falta de este servicio por el barrio donde vive para ser la primera y captar a sus clientes.

Con el crédito recibido de S/.800.00 que cancelará en 4 meses, comprará una impresora y muebles para cabinas que faltan para la implementación de su negocio.

La señora Quely tiene 40 años, vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos, quienes le apoyan en lo que ella se propone, sabe que tiene que esforzarse cada día para alcanzar sus objetivos, ella es una mujer emprendedora y muy soñadora.

loans.use: Purchase printer and furniture for her internet cafe.

loans.name: Merly Benidia

texts.es:
Mrs. Merly Benidia G. Púa, a member of the “Las Margaritas II” Communal Bank, lives in the San Martin region of Peru, in the Province of San Martin, District of Banda de Shilcayo and works as a street vendor of sweets.

She sells sweets as a street vendor at a variety of tourist attractions and amusement centers in the Morales District and downtown Tarapoto. She tells us that her husband began selling sweets as a street vendor and when she saw how well it was going for him, she decided to do it as well.

The loan of 800 soles ($275), which will be repaid over 4 months, will give her the capital to purchase cookies and crackers in a variety of flavors and brands in individual packages, bags of candies in different flavors, boxed gum of a variety of brands, chocolates, etc.

Merly is 44 years old and is a very responsible and dedicated woman. She wishes to get ahead and support her husband with the household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Merly Benidia G. Púa, socia del B. C “Las Margaritas II”, vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia de San Martín y distrito de la Banda de Shilcayo, se dedica a la venta de golosinas de manera ambulatoria.

Ella vende golosinas de manera ambulatoria por los diversos recreos turísticos y centros de diversiones del distrito de Morales y el Centro de Tarapoto, nos cuenta, que primero su pareja se dedicaba a esta actividad, ella vio que le fue muy bien y es rentable, la motivó a dedicarse a esto.

El préstamo recibido de S/. 800.00 que pagará en 4 meses, con dicho capital comprará galletas en paquetes de variados sabores y marcas, caramelos en bolsas de diversos sabores, chicles en cajas de diferentes marcas, chocolates, etc.

Ella tiene 44 años de edad, es una mujer muy responsable, decidida, con deseos de salir adelante y apoyar a su esposo en los gastos de la casa.

loans.use: Purchase wholesale sweets.

loans.name: Sofia

texts.es:
Mrs. Sofía F. Meléndez is a member of the “Women on the Path Toward Development” Communal Bank. She lives in the San Martin region of Peru, in the San Martin Province, Morales District. She sells groceries, school supplies, and beauty products from a business in her own home, which is located on Jr. Salaverry St. #198 in the Morales District.

Mrs. Sofía is separated, which has motivated her to keep struggling every day. She has a daughter who is her encouragement to not give up and keep going with all of her planned goals.

With the loan of 2,000 soles ($700), which she will repay over 4 months, she will buy sugar, sacks of rice, boxed preserves in a variety of brands, boxed milk in a variety of sizes and brands, boxed soap in a variety of brands, as well as sweets such as cookies and crackers, candy, soft drinks, etc., and cleaning and personal hygiene products such as brooms, detergents and other products that are popular with her customers.

Sofía is an enterprising woman who is sure of herself and has a jovial spirit. She receives her customers with a smile, and thanks to this she has won the appreciation and loyalty of her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Sofía F. Meléndez es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Rumbo al Desarrollo” vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia de San Martín y distrito de Morales, ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, útiles escolares, productos de belleza su negocio esta en su propia casa, que se ubica en el Jr. Salaverry Nº 198 del mismo distrito.

La señora Sofía es separada, lo que motivó a seguir luchando cada día, ella tiene una hija, quien es su aliento para no desmayar y seguir adelante con todas sus metas trazadas

Con el crédito recibido de S/.2,000.00 que devolverá en 4 meses, comprará: azúcar, arroz en sacos, conservas en cajas de diversas variedades de marcas, leche en cajas de diferentes tamaños y marcas, jabón en cajas de diversas marcas, además comprará golosinas como galletas, caramelos, bebidas gasificadas, etc. y artículos de limpieza y aseo personal como escobas, detergentes y productos que tienen mayor demanda entre sus clientes.

Sofía es una mujer emprendedora, segura de si misma, quien tiene el espíritu jovial que recibe a sus clientes con una sonrisa, gracias a eso se ha ganado el aprecio y la fidelidad de sus clientes.

loans.use: Purchase a variety of grocery items wholesale

loans.name: Jesús

texts.es:
Jesús A. Q. belongs to the “Women Fighters” Communal Bank. She lives in the region of San Martin, in the province of Tarapoto in the Tarapoto district. She owns a health center that is located on Jr. Jorge Chávez street.

Jesús is an infirmary health care technician. She began offering massage services to the people of the community as well as to foreigners who visit her daily upon hearing of the variety of therapies that she offers. She has succeeded in acquiring a large number of clients thanks to her charisma and good customer service.

With the loan of S/. 600.00, to be paid back over 4 months, she will purchase perfumes, incenses and candles of various colors and sizes.

Jesús lives with her husband and young son. She works tirelessly to be able to see results and to work toward her many goals for the future.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Jesús A. Q., pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Luchadoras”, vive en la región San Martín, provincia Tarapoto y distrito Tarapoto, tiene un centro de terapias integrales de salud que está ubicado en Jr. Jorge Chávez .

La señora es de profesión Técnica en enfermería, por la afinidad de su profesión, instaló el servicio de masajes integrales a la que diariamente acuden los moradores de la comunidad y personas extranjeras para realizase diversas terapias que ella oferta, logrando tener, a la fecha, gran cantidad de clientes gracias a su carisma y buen trato.

Con el crédito de S/. 600.00, el cual será devuelto en 4 meses, comprará perfumes aromáticos, inciensos, velas de distintos colores y tallados en maderas para implementar su terreno donde brinda Ayahuasca a sus clientes

La señora Jesus, vive con su esposo y su pequeño hijo, trabaja incansablemente para poder ver los resultados y sentirse útil en la vida con muchas perspectivas en el futuro.

loans.use: Purchase of aromatic perfumes, incenses, candles.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Mrs. Rosa C. B. is a member of the “Sowing a Future” Communal Bank. She lives in the San Martin region of Peru, in the Province of San Martin, District of Tarapoto. Her business is located in her own home, situated on Jr. Huallaga St. # 719, where she sells grocery items, sweets and common edible household products.

She and her son began selling fish brought from the coast but saw that it was not a very profitable business. They chose to open a small grocery store, and thanks to her perseverance, the business kept growing little by little until she had a well-stocked general store with all the items needed by residents of the neighborhood in which she lives.

With the loan of 1,000 soles ($350), which she will repay in 6 payments, she will purchase packet of noodles in different varieties, preserved fish in boxes, sacks of rice and sugar, liters of oil, bulk detergent of various brands, soft drinks, sweets, and personal hygiene products. She wants her customers to be able to be able to find everything they need or are looking for in the same place.

Mrs. Rosa is 52 years old and feels very sure of herself. She is known as a fighter (for what she wants), a very hard-working and responsible woman, and is very perseverant. She dreams of having a Mini-Market and being able to assure the wellbeing of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Rosa C. B., es socia del Banco Comunal “Sembrando Futuro” vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia de San Martín y distrito de Tarapoto su negocio está ubicado en su propia casa situado en el Jr Huallaga Nº 719, en el cual vende abarrotes en general, golosinas y otros productos comestibles de consumo diario.

Ella junto con su hijo se inicio vendiendo pescado traídos de la costa y vio que este trabajo no era muy rentable y opto por la venta de abarrotes gracias a su perseverancia en el trabajo hizo que poco a poco vaya creciendo hasta llegar a tener una bodega surtida con todos aquellos artículos que son de requeridos por los moradores del barrio en el que vive.

Con el préstamo recibido de S/. 1000.00 que pagara en 6 cuotas, comprará fideos en paquetes de distintas variedades conservas de pescado en cajas, arroz y azúcar en sacos, aceite en litros y a granel detergentes de diferentes marcas, bebidas gasificadas, golosinas y productos de aseo personal, quiere que sus clientes encuentren todo lo que buscan y necesitan en un mismo lugar.

La señora Rosa tiene 52 años se siente muy segura de si misma se caracteriza por ser una mujer luchadora, muy trabajadora responsable y perseverante, sueña con tener su Minimark y asegurar el bienestar de su familia.

loans.use: Purchase a variety of grocery products wholesale

loans.name: Rosabeth

texts.es:
Rosabeth D. A., partner of the Communal Bank "Women on the Course to Development," lives in the Province of San Martín in the Morales District. Her business is located in her own home in the Jr. Ayacucho block of the Morales District; she purchases and sells many varieties of rice.

Not being able to count on the financial support of her spouse and having the responsibility of educating her children, she decided to start a business buying and selling rice by the kilo. Soon thereafter she had the idea to begin to seed and to harvest rice. Nowadays, she sells her product by the sack and feels proud of her accomplishments.

WIth a loan of S/. 1,000.00 to be re-paid within 4 months, she will purchase sacks of rice for retail sales to clients who visit her daily, as well as seed for planting and fertilizers.

Rosabeth is 41 years old with 3 dependent children. She is dedicated to this business because she enjoys it and because it enables her to satisfy the needs of her household. Above all, her business enables her to educate her children. She is strong, perservering and calm, with a fighting spirit.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Rosabeth D. A., socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Rumbo Al Desarrollo”, vive en el Departamento y Provincia de San Martín, Distrito de Morales su negocio está ubicado en su propia casa en el Jr. Ayacucho cuadra 4 en el Distrito a Morales, tiene por actividad la compra y venta de arroz pilado de todas las variedades.

Al no contar con el apoyo económico de su esposo y tener la responsabilidad de educar a sus menores hijos, ella decide iniciar en el negocio de compra y venta de arroz pilado, por kilos, luego tuvo la idea empezar a sembrar y cosechar arroz, que los vende en sacos hoy en día se siente orgullosa por sus logros.

Con el préstamo recibido de S/. 1,000.00, que será pagado en 4 meses comprará: arroz por sacos para ser vendidos por kilos al por menor a sus clientes que diariamente la visitan, así como semilla para sembrar y fertilizantes.

Tiene 41 años de edad, con 03 hijos dependientes, ella se dedica a este negocio porque le gusta y de esa manera satisfacer las necesidades de la casa sobre todo poder educar a sus hijos, siempre se caracterizó por ser fuerte, perseverante, tranquila y luchadora.

loans.use: Purchase of sacks of rice, seed and fertilizers.

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en: Youssef, a 44-year-old married man, father of 1 child, lives in the area of Nabatieh in South Lebanon. Youssef uses his small truck to sell vegetables around his town and from one village market to other. He needs the amount of USD 1,200 to purchase a bigger pick-up truck. Once he gets this larger truck, he will be able to increase the merchandise he is selling and therefore increase his income and improve the livelihood of his family. Youssef has been a client of Al Majmoua for the past 4 years and always repays his loan on time.

loans.use: USD 1,200 to purchase a bigger pick-up truck

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.es:
Alejandrina M. G. D. Paz belongs to the "La Violetas II" Communal Bank. She lives in the San Martín region, Rioja province, in the district of Nueva Cajamarca. Her business is located in the local market and she sells fruit which grows in the region.

When she separated from her husband, and with the need to support her children, her only idea was to start up a business selling fruit. She got a stand in the market, and thanks to her own efforts managed to increase her sales and to gain the appreciation and admiration of many customers.

With a loan of 1,000 soles, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy some of the local fruit, such as: oranges, mandarin oranges, sweet granadilla (grenadia), taperiba, coconas, ripe bananas and green bananas, and papayas, so that she can have her stand stocked and meet the demand of her customers.

Alejandrina is 48 years old and every day works to show that she is an enterprising woman who stops at nothing to reach her goals.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Alejandrina M. Garcia D. Paz pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Violetas II,” vive en la región San Martín, provincia D. Rioja y distrito Nueva Cajamarca, su negocio está ubicado en el mercado D. la misma localidad se dedica a la venta D. frutas propias D. la zona.

Al separarse D. su esposo y con el afán D. sacar adelante a sus hijos no tuvo mejor idea que iniciarse en el negocio D. venta D. frutas, para ello consiguió un puesto en el mercado, gracias al esfuerzo propio ha logrado incrementar sus ventas, habiendo ganado el aprecio y la acogida D. una gran clientela.

Con el crédito D. S/.1,000.00,el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará diversas frutas D. la región como: naranjas, mandarinas, granadillas, taperiva, coconas en cientos, plátanos y guineos en racimos, papayas, para así tener abastecido su puesto y satisfacer la exigencia D. sus clientes.

Alejandrina tiene 48 años, trabaja diariamente demostrando que es una mujer emprendedora que para cumplir sus metas no hay límites.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of fruit.

loans.name: Malek

texts.en: Malek, 47 years old, lives in a small village close to Nabatieh in South Lebanon. He is a married man with 4 children. He owns a small clothes shop next to his home. He needs the amount of USD 1,000 to purchase from wholesalers perfumes and accessories for women. With the beginning of the summer season, there is an increased demand for such products. This inventory increase will allow Malek to expand his business by attracting more clients. Malek has been a client of Al Majmoua for the past 4 years and always repays his loan on time.

loans.use: USD 1,000 to purchase from wholesalers perfumes and accessories for women

loans.name: Fadel

texts.en: Fadel, a 45-year-old married man, father of 3 children, lives in the area of Nabatieh in South Lebanon. Fadel is a car painter. He needs a loan for the amount of USD 1,000 to purchase painting equipment and therefore expand his business. Furthermore, he needs to pay the school fees for his elder child. Fadel has been a micro-credit client of Al Majmoua for the past 2 years and always repays his loan on time.

loans.use: USD 1,000 to purchase painting equipment

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en: Bilal, 27 years old, lives in a village close to Nabatieh in South Lebanon. He is the owner of an electronics shop and needs the amount of USD 1,200 to purchase more merchandise and diversify his inventory of goods. Indeed, at the time being, Bilal’s shop cannot answer the demand of all his clients in terms of choice and brands. This is the first time Bilal has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: USD 1,200 to purchase more merchandise and diversify his inventory of goods

loans.name: Farajallah

texts.en: Farajallah, 43 years old, is married and has 2 children. He lives in the area of Nabatieh in South Lebanon and owns a vegetable and fruit shop. Farajallah needs a loan for the amount of USD 1,200 to enlarge and diversify the inventory of goods he can offer to his clients. Farajallah has been a micro-credit client of Al Majmoua for the past 6 years and always repays his debts on time. He is a very responsible man whose priority in life is the happiness of his family.

loans.use: USD 1,200 to enlarge and diversify the inventory of goods he can offer to his clients

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan, 32 years old, is married and has 1 child. He owns a furniture-making shop in a small village close to Nabatieh in South Lebanon. Hassan needs a loan for the amount of USD 1,200 to renovate his house that was damaged during the July 2006 War. This is the second time Hassan has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. He successfully repaid his previous loan on time.

loans.use: USD 1,200 to renovate his house that was damaged during the war.

loans.name: Santos

texts.es:
Santos Cercado A. belongs to the "Las Violetas" Communal Bank. She lives in the San Martín region and Rioja Province of Nueva Cajamarca. She sells typical Peruvian cookies and desserts (roscas, kekes, suspiros, biscochos) which she sells on one corner of the market on a heavily-traveled street.

She decided to start up her business after her husband left her and she became both father and mother to 6 young children. Her business is going well and now she has also started selling soft drinks.

With a loan of 1,200 soles, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy Peruvian cookies and desserts (kekes, tortas, roscas, piononos, alfajores, suspiros) on a daily basis as well as other types of sweets, and will also buy soft drinks in different flavors, sizes and brands, so that she can meet customer demand.

Santos Cercado A. is 40 years old and has 6 children, the youngest 2 live with her. She considers herself a fighter, persistent and feels she is a great example for her children.

Her goal is to have a store where she sells clothing and to be able to give work to other persons. She believes that with this type of job, she will be able to rest somewhat.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Santos Cercado A. pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Violetas”, vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia de Rioja en Nueva Cajamarca, se dedica a la venta de dulces como: Roscas dulces, kekes, suspiros, biscochos desarrolla su negocio en la esquina del mercado ya que es una avenida muy concurrida .

Decidió iniciar su negocio después de que su esposo abandonara el hogar, ella se convirtió en padre y madre para sus 6 menores hijos, le va muy bien que ahora esta surtiendo con bebidas gasificadas.

Con el crédito recibido de S/. 1,200.00 que será pagado en 6 meses comprará diariamente dulces como, kekes, tortas, roscas, piononos, alfajores, suspiros, y demás tipos de dulces, también bebidas como gaseosas de distintos sabores, tamaños y marcas y así satisfacer la gran demanda de sus clientes.

La señora Santos Cercado A. tiene 40 años y 6 hijos, ahora vive con sus 2 últimos hijos. Se considera luchadora, perseverante y siente que es un gran ejemplo para sus hijos.

Su meta es llegar a tener tienda donde vender ropa, y poder dar trabajo a mas personas, cree que con el este tipo de actividad descansará un poco.

loans.use: Buy a variety of cookies, desserts, candies and soft drinks.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Abbas

texts.en: Abbas, a 40-year-old single man, lives in a small village close to Nabatieh in South Lebanon. Abbas is a car painter whose work is very professional. He will get married soon and needs a loan for an amount of USD 1,200 to put ceramic tile on the floor of his newly build house. This is the first time Abbas has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: USD 1,200 to put tile on the ground of his newly build house

loans.name: Moustafa

texts.en: Moustafa is a 45-year-old man, married and father of 3. He owns a hairdresser shop in a small village close to Nabatieh in South Lebanon. Moustafa needs a loan for an amount of USD 1,200 to purchase shampoo, gel, creams to be displayed in his shop. This is the first time that Moustafa has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: USD 1,200 to purchase shampoo, gel, creams to be displayed in his hairdresser shop

loans.name: Nilda Consuelo

texts.es:
Nilda Consuelo R. S. is a member of the "Virgen de la Inmaculada" Communal Bank. She lives in the San Martin province, district of Tarapoto. Her dressmaking workshop is located within her own home on Jiron 9 de Abril 298, in the same district.

When she separated from her husband and with the urgency to take care of her 5 children and be near them, she started up her dressmaking workshop, thanks to the support of her mother-in-law, who helped her at all times.

With a loan for 1,000 soles, which will be repaid in 6 monthly installments, she will buy threads in various colors, different types of materials, supplies such as elastic, doilies, embroidered ribbon, good quality bias tape in different designs and other things she needs so she can satisfy her customers.

Nilda is 55 years old and lives with one of her daughters, who is her motiviation to keep going. She is a woman who has learned to make her own decisions and to be self confident. In the future she would like to install some higher grade sewing machines in her workshop.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Nilda Consuelo R. S. es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen De La Inmaculada”, vive en de San Martín y Distrito de Tarapoto, su taller de costura esta ubicado en su propia casa ubicado en el Jr: 9 de Abril Nº 298 del mismo distrito.

Al separarse de su esposo y el afán de sacar adelante a sus 5 hijos y estar cerca de ellos decidió instalar su taller de costura gracias al apoyo brindado por su suegra quien en todo momento lo apoyó

Con el préstamo adquirido de S/. 1,000.00 que será pagado en 6 cuotas mensuales, comprará hilos de colores variados, diferentes tipos telas, materiales como: elásticos, blondas, cinta bordada, sesgos en variados diseños y de buena calidad y tener todo lo necesario para satisfacer a su clientela.

La señora Nilda tiene 55 años, vive con una de sus hijas, quien es su principal motor para seguir adelante, ella es una mujer que ha aprendido a tomar sus propias decisiones segura de si misma, desea mas adelante implementar su taller con maquinas de alta costura.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of thread and materals.

loans.name: Bank Of Hope Africa Romano 5 Group

texts.en:
Amparo lives with her husband and three teenage children in the province of El Seibo. She owns and runs a small mini-market commonly called a “colmado.” Colmados are just like grocery stores but everything is sold in small portions so that the poor only have to buy what they need. This will be Amparo’s first loan with Esperanza. With the loan money, Amparo plans to buy more products for her colmado so that she can offer more to her community.

Amparo has great plans for the future, although she is content with her life. More than anything, she wants to grow closer to God. But she also wants to be able to proviD. better for her three children so that they will always have good food and be healthy. She already owns her own little house, which she is very thankful for. One day in the far-off future, she would love to be able to buy a truck, a great luxury here where most everyone has horses or motorcycles. But she blushes to mention this because she feels so blessed already and so thankful to be able to keep progressing.

Note: This is a group loan for 5 people. All 5 associates are new to Esperanza and live in the same community as Amparo. They will be joining a group five of the already established Bank of Hope called Africa Romano. They have known each other for over 10 years and are more than willing to vouch for one another to be able to receive the loan together. In a group loan, if one person is not able to pay, the other members of the group are responsible to make up the difference.

loans.use: To grow her mini-market in order to better provide for her 3 kids.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Comité San Rafael Group

texts.es:
This group was formed in January of 2007.  Mrs. Terotita A. found out about the program from a neighbor who was part of another group and decided to contact an advisor to learn about the requirements.  She told her neighbors and they agreed on a day to have an informational meeting in which 22 women, all very nervous, formed the group named San Rafael.

Over time, many of them decided to leave the group for different reasons like travel and health among others, but each time new women were incorporated into the group.  These women, besides being housewives, have their own businesses that allow them to contribute to their families’ income.  Their activitivites include things like making clothing, candy sales, clothing sales and the sale of other food items.

The group is now in its third cycle and there are 15 members that work together.  They attend their weekly meetings and have their own savings which they already have deposited in a cooperative.

The San Rafael Group is located in Posta Gaona, a rural area outside the city of Itá.  The members wish to receive a new loan to buy merchandise like clothing, items needed to make clothing including thread, fabric, scissors and zippers, merchandise for a general store including flour, sugar, soft drinks, canned goods, other food items, candies and tobacco in addition to basic items for the home.Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.



El inicio del Grupo fue en el mes de Enero del 2.007, la señora  Terotita A. se enteró del programa por intermedio de una vecina que ya era parte de un Comité, la señora Terotita decidió comunicarse con la Asesora para conocer los requisitos, comentó con sus vecinas y confirmaron un  día para la reunión informativa, en la cual asistieron 22 señoras, todas muy ansiosas conformaron el Grupo denominado San Rafael.

Trascurriendo el tiempo, muchas de ellas decidieron salir del grupo por diferentes motivos: viajes, salud, entre otros pero a su vez nuevas señoras fueron incorporándose al grupo. Estas mujeres además de ser amas de casa, poseen sus propios negocios que les permite aportar con los ingresos de la familia y entre esas actividades citamos algunas como confección de ropas, venta de golosinas, venta de ropas, comestible, etc.

El Comité se encuentra en el 3º ciclo, son 15 integrantes que trabajan en forma conjunta, asisten a sus reuniones semanales y cuentan con un ahorro propio el cual ya tienen depositado en una Cooperativa. 

El Grupo San Rafael se encuentra localizado en Posta Gaona  una zona rural de la ciudad de Itá. Desean retirar un crédito nuevo para la compra de mercaderías como ropas, artículos para la confección de ropas como hilos, telas, tijeras, cierres, mercaderías para despensa como harina, azúcar, gaseosas, enlatados, comestibles, golosinas, tabaco, venta de productos básicos para el hogar, etc.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise like clothing, items needed to make clothing including thread, fabric, scissors and zippers, merchandise for a general store including flour, sugar, soft drinks, canned goods, other food items, candies and tobacco in addition to basic items for the home

loans.name: Zadith

texts.es:
Zadith Ríos P., partner of the "Coffee Flower" Communal Bank, lives in the San Martín region in the Moyabamba Province, District of Soritor. She is engaged in the sale of groceries generally, meats (chicken, beef, pork), snacks, and other food products for daily consumption. Her business is located in her own home, situated in the Jr. Federico Froevel No. 280 block. Local clients and passers-by visit her daily.

The idea of starting the business arose from the necessity to help the family get ahead and to support her husband, as well as to proviD. for the education of her children. In addition, she likes to be in permanent contact with her friends and clients.

With the loan of S/. 800.00 to be re-paid within 6 months, she will buy diverse grocery products including: boxed brand-name soaps (Marsella, Bolívar, Jumbo), hygienic paper in packages, preserved fish, oil by the liter, soda, rice and sacks of sugar. She will also buy vegetables and eggs to supply to her clients.

Zadith is 51 years old and lives with 2 of her children and her husband, all of whom support her in the business. Together they dream about having a clothing store and assuring the well-being of the family.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Zadith Ríos P., socia del Banco Comunal “Flor Del Cafe”, vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia D. Moyabamba distrito D. Soritor, se dedica a venta D. abarrotes en general, carnes D. ( pollo, res, y carne D. cerdo), golosinas y otros productos comestibles D. consumo diario, su negocio esta ubicado en su propia casa, ubicada en el jr Federico Froevel Nro 280, donD. diariamente acuden su clientes que son moradores D. la propia localidad o transeúntes D. lugares cercanos.

La idea del negocio, surgió ante la necesidad D. sacar adelante a la familia y apoyar a su esposo, en la educación D. sus hijos y además le gusta estar en contacto permanente con sus amigos y clientes.

Con el préstamo D. S/.800.00 para ser pagado en 6 meses, comprará diversos abarrotes como: cajas D. jabón por cada marca (Marsella, bolívar, jumbo) papel higiénico en paquetes, conservas D. pescado, aceite por litros, bebidas D. gaseosas, arroz y azúcar en sacos, también comprará verduras y huevos en javas para ofertar a sus clientes.

Zadith tiene 51 años, vive junto a sus 02 hijos y su esposo, son quienes le apoyan siempre en el negocio, juntos sueñan con tener su tienda D. ropa y asegurar el bienestar D. su familia.

loans.use:
Wholesale purchase of groceries and supplies.
Compra al por mayor de artículos diversos (abarrotes).

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.es:
Consuelo S. D. Rodríguez is a partner of the "Coffee Flower" Communal Bank in the San Martín region in the Moyabamba Province, Soritor District. She prepares and sells meals and provides a meal service to the professors of the school located next to her house, which is in the Jr. Ramón Castilla No. 896 block.

Upon being widowed and with a desire to help her children, she decided to dedicate herself to what she enjoyed so much, cooking. She chose to prepare and sell typical menu items. The business began borrowing kitchen utensils and other materials; soon they were being acquired with loans and earnings from sales.

With a loan of S/. 500.00 to be re-paid in 4 months, she would buy rice, sacks of sugar, packets of noodles, bunches of bananas, oil in bulk, and other ingredients for the preparation of the menu items that she sells daily.

Consuelo is 54 years old. She is very enthusiastic and cheered by the idea that, along with her children, she can dream of having her own store one day so that she can get some rest. While she very much enjoys cooking, the work requires many sacrifices.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Consuelo S. D. Rodríguez, es socia del Banco Comunal “Flor Del Café”, vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia D. Moyabamba y distrito D. Soritor, se dedica a la preparación y venta D. comida, y da pensión a los profesores del colegio que esta al lado D. su casa, ubicada en el jr Ramón castilla Nro 896.

Al quedar viuda y con la en el afán D. sacar adelante a sus hijos, decidió dedicarse a lo que tanto le gusta, la cocina, por eso deciD. vender comida tipo menú, el negocio empezó prestando utensilios D. cocina y otros materiales, luego los fue adquiriendo con los prestamos y las ganancias que le brinda sus ventas.

Con el préstamo D. S/. 500.00 que será devuelto en 4 meses, implementará su negocio comprando arroz, azúcar por sacos, fideos en paquetes, plátano en racimos, aceite a granel, y demás ingredientes para la preparación D. su menú que diariamente venD.

La señora Consuelo tiene 54 años, es una muy mujer entusiasta y alegre que junto a sus hijos y con la humildad que demuestra sueña con tener una bodega para que pueda descansar, si bien es cierto le gusta mucha la cocina, pero es un trabajo muy sacrificado.

loans.use:
Puchase of wholesale items of consumption.
Compra de insumos al por mayor.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa N. S. belongs to the "Coffee Flower" Communal Bank. She lives in the San Martin region in the province of Moyabamba, district of Soritor. In the market in this locality, she sells regional and coastal vegetables that are bought daily by the inhabitants of the city.

The idea of the business arose from the need to help her family and to support her husband with the education of her children. She is grateful for the opportunity of acquiring a loan that permits her to undertake her business.

With a loan of S/. 1000.00, she will buy cilantro, kilos of Chinese onions, various red peppers, potatoes, sweet potatoes, caihua, and different varieties of beans, among other items, to supplement her business and to satisfy her clients' needs.

Teresa is 47 years old and shows much energy and vitality. She enjoys developing her business because it allows her to be in contact with her friends and others who visit her business on a daily basis. She considers herself a fighter, a perseverer, and a great example for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Teresa N. S., pertenece al Banco Comunal “Flor Del Cafe”,” vive en la región San Martín, provincia de Moyabamba y distrito de Soritor, su negocio está ubicado en el mercado de dicha localidad se dedica a la venta de verduras de la región y de la costa, que diariamente es comprado por los moradores de la ciudad.

La idea del negocio surge, ante la necesidad de sacar adelante a la familia y apoyar a su esposo, con la educación de sus hijos, gracias a la oportunidad de acceder a un préstamo y permitirle emprender su negocio por el que esta muy agradecida.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1000.00 que será pagado en 4 meses, ella implementará su negocio, comprará culantro, cebolla china en kilos, ajíes de distintas variedades, papas, camotes, caihua, fréjoles de distintas variedades entre otros, para surtir su negocio y satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes.

La señora Teresa tiene 47 años, muestra mucha energía y vitalidad, además le gusta el negocio que desarrolla, pues le permite estar en contacto con sus amigos y demás personas que acuden a diario a su negocio. Se considera luchadora, perseverante y siente que es un gran ejemplo para sus hijos.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of vegetables and tubers (root crop).

loans.name: Manuel De Jesus

texts.es:
A resident of the Cantón Patzij neighborhood in the town of Nahualá, Sololá, since he was 18 years old, Jesus has worked as a craftsman carving wooden masks. By means of this work he earns the income needed to cover his expenses including food, clothing and his children’s education. He went to ASDIR in order to increase his working capital to be able to purchase raw materials and tools. Later he plans to hire or create jobs for other people to meet the demand for his products. Currently he is selling in the town of Nahualá and with a little more capital he would be selling in nearby towns and increasing his income thereby offering a better quality of life to his family.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Residente del Cantón Patzij, Nahualá, Sololá, desde que tenía 18 años se dedica a la Artesanía “Tallado de Mascaras en madera”, por medio de este trabajo obtiene sus ingresos económicos para sufragar los gastos alimenticios, ropa y estudio de sus hijos, esta persona acude a ASDIR para ampliar su capital de trabajo y así comprar materia prima y herramientas; luego piensa contratar o generar empleo a otras personas y poder cubrir la demanda de sus productos, actualmente está vendiendo en la población de Nahualá y con un poco más de capital estaría vendiendo en otros municipios cercanos y mejorar sus ingresos para brindar un mejor nivel de vida a su familia.

loans.use: Working capital to purchase raw materials and tools

loans.name: Ana Mercedes

texts.es:
Ana Mercedes M. M., a “Flor Del Café” community bank member, lives in the San Martín region, Moyabamba province, Soritor district, and sells groceries, candy and soft drinks out of her own house at 1135 Jr. Bolognesi, where the neighborhood residents come daily to make purchases. The idea for the store came out of the need to help her husband by contributing toward the household expenses and, above all, to the education of their four minor children. With this $1,000 loan, which she will repay in six moths, Ana will buy basic foodstuffs like rice, sugar, milk, oil, canned goods, pasta, detergent, toilet paper and soft drinks to meet her clients’ needs. Ana is 40, lives with her husband and four children who depend on her. Her goal is to have a grocery store and sell both wholesale and retail.

Translated from Spanish by Ian Harvey, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Ana Mercedes M. M. , es socia del Banco Comunal “Flor Del Café”, vive en la región San Martín, provincia de Moyabamba, distrito de Soritor, se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, golosinas y bebidas gaseosas, en su propia casa ubicado Jr.Bolognesi Nro 1135, donde acuden diariamente a comprar los moradores del barrio. La idea del negocio surgió por la necesidad de apoyar a su esposo, y de esta manera poder aportar económicamente en los gastos de la casa, sobretodo en la educación a sus 4 menores hijos. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 que pagará en 6 meses, comprará productos de primera necesidad como sacos de arroz, azúcar, cajas de leche, aceite, conservas, paquetes de fideos, detergentes, papel higiénico, gaseosas de distintas marcas, entre otros y así poder llegar a satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes. Tiene 40 años, vive con su esposo y sus 4 que todavía depende de ella, su meta en el futuro es tener una tienda de abarrotes y vender al por mayor y menor.

loans.use: To buy various wholesale products (groceries)

loans.name: Girasol Group

texts.en:
The group of women from the girasol (sunflower) group live in the remote town of Santa Catarina Ixtahuacan. They love their town because it is where they were born and raised. Most people in this town rely on farming for their livelihoods. The women wish to advance the education of their children, maintain a healthy family and support the work of their husbands.

Farming involves a collective family effort to buy the necessary materials, plant, care for, harvest, process and sell the crops. Among the borrowers, they grow broccoli, cauliflower, potato, carrot, onion and cabbage. Once the time consuming process of farming has been completed, they take their vegetables to the markets of Nahuala and surrounding villages to sell. During the rainy season, sales and profits are low which makes their profession a constant struggle. However, at the end of the day, it is their means of livelihood.

The loans proviD. families with credit to start a business and maintain a healthy business cycle where they can buy the necessary products, plant and harvest enough in order to keep their business profitable. With this loan, they will purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticides.

Francisca S. initially requested a loan of 50 USD and now is servicing a 400 USD loan. She hopes to defy the odds and save enough money to be able to buy a large piece of neighboring land.

loans.use: to purchase equipment, seed, fertilizer and pesticides in bulk

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
Virginia Y. De H., “Flor Del Cafe” community bank member, lives in the San Martín region, Moyabamba province, Soritor district, and her business is located in her house at 260 Jr Fray Martín in an environment especially equipped for the type of work she does, which is producing and wholesaling starch and its derivatives. She decided to go into business to help her husband pay the household expenses, manage her own income and be independent. Now she is the one sustaining the household by sending her product to the coast and keeping her regional customers supplied. Virginia will use the $500.00 loan, which she will pay back in four months, to buy sacks of yuca, which is the main element used in her production, and she will buy corrugated steel used for drying the starch and other production materials she needs so that she can meet her customers’ needs. Virginia is 59 years old and lives with her husband, who supports her in her work. She is very happy with what she is doing because it has opened up many opportunities. Her goal is to build up the business and hire people to help her in her work.

Translated from Spanish by Ian Harvey, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Virginia Y. De H., socia del Banco Comunal “Flor Del Cafe” vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia de Moyabamba distrito de Soritor, su negocio se ubica en su propia casa, en el Jr Fray Martín Nro 260 en un ambiente acondicionado especialmente para este tipo de trabajo, se dedica la elaboración y venta de almidón y sus derivados al por mayor. Decidió iniciar en el negocio para poder apoyar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y así manejar sus propios ingresos y ser una persona independiente ya que por el momento ella es el sustento de su hogar, envía su producto a la costa así como también abastece a clientes de la región El crédito de S/. 500.00, el cual será devuelto en 4 meses comprará sacos de yuca, que es el elemento principal en su actividad, también invertirá en la compra de calaminas para el secado del almidón y otros materiales necesarios para la elaboración de esta producto, y así poder atender a su exigente clientela. Tiene 59 años, vive con su esposo quien le apoya en su trabajo, esta muy contenta con lo que hace por que le abrió muchas oportunidades, su meta es crecer en el negocio y así también poder dar trabajo a personas quienes la apoyan en esta labor.

loans.use: To buy corrugated steel and wholesale yuca

loans.name: Ulda

texts.es:
Ms. Ulda H. is a very focused woman who dedicates herself to agricultural labor and pursuits by raising livestock. She has been doing this work from a very young age, having been brought up and experienced in an agricultural lifestyle in the borough of El Sauce, in the city of León.

Today, what brings her to Ceprodel is her need for a loan, which she will use to buy calves to develop her livestock and at the same time, maintain her humble home for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

La señora Ulda H. es una muy esforzada dama que se dedica a la labor agropecuaria en la crianza de ganado y asistencia a los cultivos. Se dedica a esto desde muy jovencita habiéndose desarrollado y alcanzado experiencia en el trabajo agropecuario en el municipio de El Sauce de la ciudad de León.

Hoy en día el motivo por el cual acude a Ceprodel es para solicitar un crédito para la compra de terneros como ganado con el propósito de proceder a su respectiva crianza y a la vez continuar con el mantenimiento de su humilde familia.

loans.use: buy calves

loans.name: Girasol Ii Group

texts.en:
The women from the Girasol II loan group are from Santa Catarina Ixtahuacan, a very small town in the highlands. They enjoy working together and are excited to access a loan. The women that comprise the Girasol II group raise livestock for a living. They buy and sell cows and bulls of different ages. Some of them sell the grown animal while others butcher it and sell the meat to butcher shops. They raise the cattle over a period of time and have established a business cycle. Most of their families have other means of income apart from raising livestock and dedicate a part of their land for grazing purposes.

Despite the rise in the price of a grown cow or bull from 300 to 800 USD, purchasing calves and raising them involve substantial costs. The animals are raised for 7 to 8 months. Since raising cattle involves an initial investment, being able to access loans is very important. Loans give these families a safety net which allows them to invest in feed, corn and vitamins for the cattle.

The credit has allowed them to grow their business and investments bit by bit. Most of these women began with small loans of under 50 USD. Today, they borrow and repay loans that are on average from 300 to 400 USD.

Reyna G. began her micro-enterprise raising and selling chicken. Currently, she is raising half a dozen of her own cattle. She described her venture as separate from her husband’s affairs. She takes out the loan, raises the cattle, sells the meat and repays the loans after making a profit. The loans provide her with the flexibility to maintain her own cattle business while raising three children.

Money is on these womens' minds very often, so that they can support a happy, healthy and prosperous family. Their livelihood is contingent upon having the peace of mind that there is cash to cover expenses while they build a sustainable business.

loans.use: to purchase vitamins, cattle feed and other fencing equipment

loans.name: Yesenia Yulisa

texts.es:
Yesenia is a member of the "Flor Del Cafe" community bank. She lives in the Peruvian "region" of San Martin and earns a living making and selling cakes for events such as weddings, "quinceanos" (a traditional celebration for girls at their 15-year birthday), birthday parties, etc. She also makes and sells "biscochuelos" (a traditional bun maD. with sugar and spices). When Yesenia first started her business, she was a little unsure of herself because she didn't know much about the bakery business. She feared that she would lose her investment if she couldn't sell her products quickly, because they would spoil, but she soon perfected her technique and learned what her customers wanted, and her business has grown bit by bit.

With the S/.1200 (1200 Peruvian soles) loan, to be repaid in 6 months, Yesenia will buy the ingredients that she needs to make her cakes--sugar, flour, eggs, butter, milk and coloring for decorating the cakes, along with ingredients and supplies for making biscochuelos.

Yesenia, 33, has 2 children. She's a woman with a vision of the future and the confidence to overcome any obstacle to her plans to have a pastry shop.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Yesenia Maldonado es socia del Banco Comunal “Flor Del Café” vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia D. Moyabamba y distrito D. Soritor, se dedica a la preparación y venta D. diferentes tipos y variedades D. tortas, para diferentes ocasiones como matrimonios, quinceaños, cumpleaños, etc., así como también D. biscochuelos. Aun inicio del negocio ella, sentía un poco D. inseguridad por la falta D. experiencia y conocimiento en dicho negocio, sobre todo por el temor a perder su capital al no vender lo preparado ya que este producto es D. rápido consumo, pero con el transcurrir D. los días perfeccionando su técnica y conociendo a sus clientes, que poco a poco fue aumentando,

Con el crédito D. S/. 1,200.00, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará los ingredientes que necesita para la preparación D. sus tortas como: azúcar en sacos, harina preparada en paquetes, huevos en jabas, mantequilla en paquetes, leches en cajas y colorantes para el decorado D. las tortas, y demás ingredientes y accesorios para la preparación D. biscochuelos.

Ella tiene 33 años y 2 hijos, es una mujer con mucha visión D. futuro, y segura D. si misma que pueD. vencer cualquier obstáculo, por lo que piensa tener su pastelería.

loans.use: Buy supplies for bakery business.

loans.name: Flor Económico Group

texts.en:
The women from the group Flor Economico are happy living in their small town of Santa Lucia Utatlan. The women are a group of neighbors who always help each other out with meeting times, repayment dates and educational meetings. They live in a town which is “friendly and nice,” as Maria Salome M. described it. Although small, the villagers as hardworking men and women who search to find successful jobs and business opportunities.

These women are dedicated owners of an embroidery micro-enterprise. They dedicate their time to weaving the colorful embroidery commonly seen in tops, known as guipiles, in the Lake Atitlan region. Five of them hire employees to work along with them. On average, they complete ten to fifteen tops in a month and sell them at 500 to 700 quetzales (80-100 USD) each, depending on the style and quality.

They sell their finished products to buyers at the Nahuala, Solola, Santa Clara, Chimaltenango and Quiche markets. Some of them work based on orders. Their sales are continuously growing thanks to their ability to increase production.

Their current sales have dropped due to the seasonal rain and a bad economy. Their confidence is unhindered, however, as they are confident that sales will rebound in the December, January and February. The loans help to stabilize their financial cycle during low seasons or months where there are unforeseen family expenses.

The loans provide them with capital to deal with higher prices and access low interest loans. They can now invest in their business and hire workers to assist them. The current loan request will go towards buying cloth, string, and art supplies. The rainy season is when loans are needed most.

These working mothers have consistently repaid their loans and strive to improve and grow their micro-enterprises. They are working towards a future in which they have a large, sustainable business that does not need loans. This will allow them to support their families and husbands.

loans.use: to purchase thread for embroidery

loans.name: Luz Janeth

texts.es:
Luz belongs to the "Las Riojanitas" ("The Rioja Girls") community bank. She lives in the Peruvian "region" of San Martin and earns a living buying and selling fresh fish brought inland from the coast. She built her business working at home and selling in the surrounding neighborhood. Her goal was to support herself working at home and after trying various businesses, she decided on buying and selling fresh fish.

With the S/.3000 (3000 Peruvian soles) loan, to be repaid in 6 months, she will buy bulk supplies of fresh fish, of all types and sizes, along with ice to keep it fresh.

Luz lives with her husband and 4 children, all of whom support her. She works tirelessly so that she can see the results of her work and feel useful. She has a lot of plans for the future, one of which is to have a shop in her house.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Luz Yaneth R. H. pertenece al Banco de Crédito “LAS RIOJANITAS”, vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia de RIOJA, distrito de Rioja, se dedica a la venta al por mayor y menor de pescado fresco traídos de la costa, desarrolla su negocio en su domicilio que está ubicado en el jr Raymondi, y propia casa y recorriendo comunidades cercanas. Con la finalidad de apoyar económicamente en el hogar, y después de probar en otros tipos de negocio decide cambiar de negocio, ahora se dedica a la compra y venta de pescado fresco traídos de la costa.

Con el crédito de S/. 3000.00 el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará pescado fresco traídos de la costa, en mayor cantidad de todo tamaño y variedad y comprar hielo en barra para conservarlos frescos

La señora Luz Yaneth, vive con sus 4 hijos y su esposo quienes lo apoyan, trabaja incansablemente para poder ver los resultados y sentirse útil en la vida, ella tiene con muchas perspectivas en el futuro una de ellas es tener su tienda en su casa.

loans.use: Buy products and supplies for retail shop.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Dilsa

texts.es:
Dilsa Diaz Y. is a member of the "Las Flores" Communal Bank. she lives in the San Martín region, in the Rioja province, district of Rioja. Her business is located at Jiron Atahualpa, block 4, and she sells straw which is used to make hats, purses and other objects.

The idea for this business came from her husband, who realized how much in demand this material was and that she could generate her own income, improving the family´s economy. With much effort she has been able to increase her business and gain the admiration and acceptance of many customers.

With a loan of 500 soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy straw from farms. Later she will process the straw and send it to her customers - both those on the coast as well as in her region of the country - in accordance with what they have ordered.

Dilsa is 29 years old. Every day she works to prove she is an enterprising woman who meets her goals, and that they can be reached with hard work and dedication. In the future, she plans to have a grocery store and to be a wholesaler.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Dilsa Diaz Y., es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Flores” vive en la región San Martín, provincia de Rioja y distrito de Rioja, su negocio está ubicado en el jr Atahualpa cuadra 4, se dedica a la venta de paja para la fabricación de sus derivados como los sombreros, carteras, y demás objetos a base de este material.

La idea del negocio surgió de su esposo por que se dio cuenta que es un material muy requerido, y que generaría sus propios ingresos, mejorando la economía de su hogar , con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado incrementar su negocio, habiendo ganado el aprecio y la acogida de una gran clientela.

Con el préstamo recibido de S/.500.00, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará paja en las chacras para luego procesarlo y enviarlo a sus clientes de acuerdo a los pedidos que hacen al por mayor, tanto a sus clientes de la costa como de la misma región.

La señora Dilsa tiene 29 años, quien trabaja diariamente demostrando que es una mujer emprendedora y que para cumplir sus metas, se puedan alcanzar con esfuerzo y dedicación, en el futuro piensa tener una tienda de abarrotes y ser mayorista.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of straw.

loans.name: Santa Marta Group

texts.en:
The women from the Santa Marta community in San Juan, Lake Atitlan enjoy living in their town and prefer to work in groups. Group president Albertina U. described their habits as, “tranquil, united and happy.” All of these women know each other and it is easy to sense that they enjoy being part of a team in which everyone pays back their loans as a group.

The women dedicate themselves to a variety of micro-enterprises. Eight women weave - making hammocks, traditional guipil tops and shoulder bags. Three women resell clothing. The other two raise chickens to sell or butcher. Their buyers are intermediaries who sell items in Panajachel and other villages surrounding Lake Atitlan.

When asked about their businesses, they had mixed feelings. Although sales are continuously growing, the sales were low this season. The winter months of December, January and February bring in much more profit than the rainy season of the spring months.

According to Albertina U., the loans have helped a lot and have allowed them to invest in necessities for their businesses. This will ultimately lead to increased profits. She pointed out that sometimes the cycle of a business is interrupted when an unforeseen expense arises or sales are low. The loans help to keep the businesses stable. However, this cycle is broken when there’s a lack of microlenders.

The loans support their business but more importantly support most of their dreams for the future: “the well-being of their families and the advancement of their childrens' education.”

loans.use: to purchase weaving equipment, thread, dye and cloth

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucia is a member of the "Las Flores" community bank. She lives in the Peruvian "region" of San Martin and operates a general store, selling a variety of products from her shop. Thanks to her perseverance, with the support of her husband and children, Lucia has managed to grow the business significantly and she now has a well-stocked store offering a range of products to customers who come to her day after day.
